context: COVID-19 deaths by month
target: This SPARQL query counts the number of human deaths (wd:Q5) caused by COVID-19 (wd:Q84263196) recorded in Wikidata, grouped by month and year. It filters death dates (P570) with high precision (at least month-level) between January 2019 and December 2021, then extracts the month and year from each death date to aggregate the total deaths per month-year period.

context: Movies by rate of actors who studied at RADA (When distribution has at last 5 actors)
target: This SPARQL query finds movies with at least 5 actors and calculates the proportion of those actors who studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA). It first counts RADA-trained actors per movie, then the total actors per movie (filtering for movies with 5+ actors), and finally computes the ratio of RADA actors to total actors, listing movies ordered by this ratio in descending order.

context: Central libraries in California linked to their branch library
target: This SPARQL query retrieves library systems in California, linking each central library to its branch libraries. It fetches their names, coordinates, and creates geographic lines (LINESTRING) connecting each central library to its branches. This enables mapping the spatial relationships within library systems, visualizing how branches relate to their central hubs across California.

context: Writers in the SIEFAR dictionary with a portrait in Wikimedia Commons
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of women writers featured in the SIEFAR dictionary (identified by property P7962) who belong to the broader occupation category of writers (P106 with subclass Q36180). For each writer, it fetches their name, a portrait image from Wikimedia Commons if available (P18), and constructs a link to their SIEFAR dictionary entry. Results are grouped by writer and ordered by the SIEFAR ID.

context: Place and date of birth of people buried at Père Lachaise Cemetery (one color per century of birth)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about people buried at Père Lachaise Cemetery (Q311). For each person, it gets their birth date, birthplace coordinates, grave plot number, and optionally a photo of their grave. It also fetches French Wikipedia articles about them. The query categorizes individuals by birth century (e.g., 18th, 19th) to enable color-coding on a map, showing their burial locations and historical context.

context: Occupations of people on Wikidata dying of coronavirus (politician ranks higher than the next 3 occupations combined)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 100 occupations of people on Wikidata who died from coronavirus (COVID-19). It selects individuals (wd:Q5) with cause of death set to coronavirus (wd:Q84263196), counts how many belong to each occupation (wdt:P106), and returns occupation labels with their counts. Results are ordered by descending count, highlighting that politicians rank highest, exceeding the next three occupations combined.

context: Things Donald Trump and others own / have owned
target: This SPARQL query retrieves items owned or previously owned by Donald Trump (Q22686) and related entities. It first finds all items connected to Trump via the "owns/owned" property (P1830), including indirect ownership. For each item, it optionally fetches the owner, their images, and item details like labels and descriptions. The query also pulls human-readable labels in the preferred language.

context: Graveplots by gender in Père Lachaise Cemetery
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about people buried in Père Lachaise Cemetery (wd:Q311), focusing on their grave locations and related media. It fetches each person's burial plot coordinates, optional photos of the person and their grave, and links to French Wikipedia articles about them. Additionally, it groups individuals by gender (occupation property P21) to create map layers, labeling and describing each person in French or English.

context: Co-authorship between researchers from National University of La Plata
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of co-authors linked to the National University of La Plata (wd:Q784171) who have collaborated on specific types of publications like journal articles, books, and conference papers. It excludes self-links and retrieves each author’s label and image if available. The query also assigns a default white color ("FFFFFF") to each author node for visualization purposes.

context: Number of Harvard Law graduates dead by year between 1850 and 1950
target: This SPARQL query counts how many Harvard Law School graduates died each year between 1850 and 1950. It selects people (wd:Q5) who graduated from Harvard Law (wd:Q49122) and have a recorded date of death (P570). It extracts the year from each death date, filters for dates within the specified range, then groups and counts the number of deaths per year, suitable for visualizing trends over time.

context: Visualization of the works of Charles Heaphy
target: This SPARQL query retrieves artworks created by Charles Heaphy (wd:Q1064767) along with their related items for visualization. It fetches two groups: first, Heaphy’s works and their types (colored bright orange, size 2), and second, works depicting other items (colored yellow, size 1). For each, it gets images and labels to help visually distinguish original works from depictions in a graph view.

context: Identifiers present on the item for Penelope Cruz (or other movie people), but not on the item for Sean Connery
target: This SPARQL query finds external identifier properties that exist for Penelope Cruz (wd:Q39666) but are missing for Sean Connery (wd:Q4573). It lists these identifiers, excluding certain property types, and retrieves example URLs constructed from these IDs. The query helps compare which unique external IDs Penelope Cruz has that Sean Connery does not, useful for data completeness checks in Wikidata.

query:
#defaultView:Map
SELECT * WHERE {
  ?q wdt:P5375 ?id .
  ?q wdt:P569 ?date .
  ?q wdt:P19/wdt:P625 ?coord .
  BIND ( floor(year(?date)/100) AS ?layer )
}
context: Map of places of birth of people with an identifier Inter-university Health Library in Wikidata colored by century of birth
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people who have an Inter-university Health Library ID (wdt:P5375), their birth dates (wdt:P569), and birthplaces' coordinates (wdt:P19/wdt:P625). It calculates the birth century by dividing the birth year by 100 and flooring it, assigning this to ?layer. This enables mapping birthplaces colored by century on a map.

context: Terminus locations of A Roads in Britain
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the end points (termini) of A Roads in Britain. It selects each road classified as an A Road, finds its terminus, and obtains the geographic coordinates of that terminus. The query also fetches English labels for both the terminus and the road, enabling mapping or visualization of where these roads end.

context: POTUS/UK PM age at inauguration/appointment and England mean age
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the ages at the start of office for U.S. presidents and UK prime ministers, along with the mean age of England’s population over time. It combines three datasets: the age of each leader at inauguration or appointment date, and England’s average age at specific times. The results include the date, age, and category ("US president," "UK Prime Minister," or "England") for comparative analysis.

context: Map of (public-sector) winners of H2020 projects in the Netherlands sortable by year
target: This SPARQL query retrieves public-sector winners of Horizon 2020 projects in the Netherlands, including their project items, labels, locations, and coordinates. It extracts project start years (2013–2020) to categorize results into yearly layers for map visualization. The query orders results by start year, enabling a time-filtered, clustered map view of Dutch H2020 project locations.

context: People who have held the positions of both Vice President and President of the United States
target: This SPARQL query retrieves individuals who have served as both Vice President (wd:Q11699) and President (wd:Q11696) of the United States. For each person, it fetches their name (P1559) and, if available, an image (P18). The query returns distinct results, ensuring each person appears only once with their name and optional photo.

context: Crew of missions to the ISS and human spaceflights that have docked with the ISS
target: This SPARQL query counts distinct crew members born in each country who participated in expeditions to the International Space Station (ISS) or were part of significant events involving spacecraft docking with the ISS. It groups results by country, retrieving country names and ordering them by the number of crew members, highlighting nations contributing most to ISS missions.

query:
select (str(?decade) as ?dec) (count(distinct ?ps) as ?count) ?causeLabel   where
{
  ?mp p:P39 ?ps . ?ps ps:P39 ?term . ?term wdt:P279 wd:Q16707842 . 
  ?ps pq:P582 ?pend . filter not exists { ?mp p:P39 ?ps2 . ?ps2 ps:P39 ?term . ?ps2 pq:P580 ?pend } 
  # not new term starting same day - ie left Parliament
  ?ps pq:P1534 ?cause . 
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q741182 } # not dissolution
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q7649223 } # not suspension
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q35855188 } # tofix
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q36345696 } # tofix
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q30580660 } # tofix
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q52084147 } # tofix
  filter not exists { ?ps pq:P1534 wd:Q35867887 } # tofix
  bind(year(?pend) as ?year) . filter(?year >= 1880) . bind((floor(?year/10)*10) as ?decade) .
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
} group by ?causeLabel ?decade order by ?causeLabel
#defaultView:BarChart
context: Graph of reasons UK MPs have left Parliament, grouped by decade since the 1890s
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of UK MPs who left Parliament each decade since 1880, grouped by the reason for their departure. It filters out cases like dissolutions or suspensions, focusing on distinct end-of-term events without immediate reappointments. The results show counts per cause and decade, enabling visualization of exit reasons over time.

context: Number of successful UK election petitions by parliamentary term, 1859 onwards (includes by-elections as well as general elections)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves UK parliamentary terms (subclasses of a specific term class) starting after 1858, counting distinct successful election petitions linked to each term. It groups results by term and start date, returning the term label, start year, and petition count, sorted from newest to oldest. The output visualizes election petition trends over time.

context: List of longest Cars
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the 50 longest cars from Wikidata. It selects items classified as cars (wd:Q1420) or their subclasses, fetching their length (property P2043) and labels in English. Results are ordered by length in descending order, showing the biggest cars first, with a fallback sort by name. The output is a table of car names and their lengths.

context: Rivers and canals in the United Kingdom
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct UK locations (`?item`) labeled in English, along with their coordinates (`?coord`) and associated canals or rivers (`?canal`), focusing on waterways classified as rivers or canals (`wd:Q4022` or `wd:Q12284`). It gathers labels for both places and waterways, ensuring the waterways belong to the specified types, then orders results by the waterway's name (`?canalLabel`).

context: Map of images taken for the Wicipics photography campaign in Wales
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct items related to the Wicipics photography campaign in Wales (identified by property P5008 with value Q101553389). For each item, it fetches its coordinates (P625), image (P18), type (P31), and labels/descriptions in Welsh or English. The results can be visualized on a map, showing photos with their locations and categories.

context: Number of people and terms of UK parties since the 1945 election
target: This SPARQL query retrieves UK political parties along with the count of distinct people and their terms who held positions classified under a specific role (Q16707842) since 1945. It groups data by party, counting unique individuals and terms linked to each party, then orders the results by the number of people in descending order, providing insight into party representation post-1945.

context: UK MPs who have voluntarily resigned their seats and then come back for a different seat in the same Parliament
target: This SPARQL query finds UK MPs who voluntarily resigned their parliamentary seat during a term and were later re-elected to a different seat in the same Parliament. It lists each MP, their original and new seats, resignation and re-election dates, and the time gap between these events. The query ensures no other terms overlap this period, highlighting MPs who switched constituencies mid-term.

context: Media articles, public documents and academic references on backward/cluster-focused contact tracing (including models)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 items related to backward or cluster-focused contact tracing (identified by the Wikidata entity Q98969121). For each item, it fetches the English label, DOI (digital object identifier), and the journal where it was published, if available. It also optionally checks for associated images, enriching the data with publication details and identifiers.

query:
SELECT distinct  ?itemLabel ?date ?sourcePropertyLabel ?referenceLabel ?reference 
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P39/wdt:P279 wd:Q1285463.
  ?item p:P569 ?dateStatement.
  ?dateStatement a wikibase:BestRank; # simulate wdt:
                 ps:P569 ?date.
  OPTIONAL{
    ?dateStatement prov:wasDerivedFrom [ ?source ?reference ].
    ?sourceProperty wikibase:reference ?source.
  }
  
  ?item p:P39 ?decla.
  ?decla pq:P580 ?ddebut.
  FILTER NOT EXISTS {?decla pq:P582 ?dfin. }
  FILTER (?date > "1952-01-01T00:00:00+00:00"^^xsd:dateTime)
   SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],fr". }.

}
context: Date of birth of current French prefects and their sources
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the names and birth dates of current French prefects (officials in administrative roles) born after January 1, 1952. It ensures the prefects are actively in office by checking for a start date without an end date. The query also fetches the source properties and references that verify each birth date, providing detailed provenance for the data.

context: Living 'notable' people with the given name "Karen" per 100k per country
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of living notable people named "Karen" in each country, calculates their count per 100,000 inhabitants, and ranks countries accordingly. It filters out deceased individuals, groups results by country, includes population data, and returns country names, counts, populations, and the normalized rate for easy comparison.

context: Paintings in the Suter Art Gallery
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all paintings housed in the Suter Art Gallery (identified by Q61797555). It selects distinct items classified as paintings (Q3305213) that belong to this collection. For each painting, it fetches the label, description, and optionally an image if available. The results are displayed with multilingual labels using Wikidata’s label service.

context: Chilean ministers who were not educated at any high school
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of living Chilean politicians who have held positions classified under "ministerial office" (or its subclasses) but were **not educated at any high school**. It filters for Chilean nationals (country = Chile), excludes those with a recorded date of death, and removes anyone linked to an educational institution that is a high school, ensuring the politicians returned lack high school education records.

context: Age of US presidents start and end time
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about people (wd:Q5) who have held the position of US President (wd:Q11696). For each president, it gets their date of birth (?dob), the start (?start) and optional end (?end) dates of their presidency, and calculates their age at the start (?age1) and end (?age2) of their term. It also optionally computes the time lived after leaving office (?rest). Results are labeled and ordered by age at presidency start, descending.

context: Map of Welsh Railways
target: This SPARQL query finds railway stations in Wales connected by tracks, starting from a specific station (Q1990205). It uses a breadth-first search to explore linked stations, retrieving each station’s coordinates, the railway track connecting it to adjacent stations, and optional images. The query outputs geographic linestrings for mapping the railway network visually.

context: Connections of railways of the Netherlands
target: This SPARQL query finds railway stations in the Netherlands connected to a specific station (wd:Q1990205) using a breadth-first search. It retrieves each station’s coordinates, the railway tracks linking them, and builds geographic linestrings representing connections. Additionally, it fetches station labels and images, enabling a map visualization of the Dutch railway network.

context: Distinct languages of Wikidata lexemes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of languages used in Wikidata lexemes, counting how many unique lexemes each language has. It then orders the languages by this count in descending order. The query also fetches readable language labels for display, making it ideal for visualizing language distribution in lexemes, such as in a bubble chart.

query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?gizaki ?gizakiLabel ?jaiolekuaLabel ?heriotzalekuaLabel ?year ?layer ?data (CONCAT(STR(?year), "-01-01 00:00:00") as ?concat) ?lat ?lon ?lat2 ?lon2 WHERE {
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
  ?gizaki wdt:P31 wd:Q5;
    (wdt:P19/(wdt:P131*)/^wdt:P527) wd:Q47588.
  ?gizaki wdt:P19 ?jaiolekua.
  ?jaiolekua p:P625 ?koordenatuak. 
  ?koordenatuak psv:P625 ?koord. 
  ?koord wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat. 
  ?koord wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon. 
  ?gizaki wdt:P570 ?data.
  BIND(YEAR(?data) as ?year).
  BIND(FLOOR((?year-1)/100)+1 AS ?mende).
  BIND(?mende as ?layer)
  ?gizaki wdt:P20 ?heriotzalekua.
  ?heriotzalekua p:P625 ?koordenatuak2. 
  ?koordenatuak2 psv:P625 ?koord2. 
  ?koord2 wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat2. 
  ?koord2 wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon2. 
}
context: Death place of all Basque people with known birthplace on Wikipedia, by century
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct Basque individuals (humans) born in the Basque Country (Q47588) along with their birth and death places. For each person, it fetches labels, birth and death coordinates (latitude and longitude), and the year of death. It calculates the century of death as a “layer” for grouping, and formats the death year as a timestamp. This helps analyze death locations of Basque-born people by century.

context: Aberdeen recycling centers and recycling points
target: This SPARQL query retrieves recycling locations within Aberdeen by selecting items classified as either recycling centers (wd:Q47520309) or recycling points (wd:Q27106436). It filters places located in Aberdeen (wd:Q62274582), fetching their coordinates, labels, and descriptions. The results are ready for mapping, showing detailed info about each recycling site.

context: Map of Semantic Web in Libraries 2020 participant's institutions
target: This SPARQL query retrieves institutions of participants from the Semantic Web in Libraries 2020 event, linking them to their Wikidata entries. It fetches each institution’s name, participant count, logo, image, and geographic coordinates by prioritizing the most precise location available. The results enable mapping these institutions with enriched visual and spatial data.

context: Women who play chess and have a Wikipedia article in Spanish
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 500 distinct women who are chess players and have a Wikipedia article in Spanish. It looks for entities classified as chess players (P106: occupation = Q10873124) and female (P21: sex or gender = Q6581072). Then, it finds Spanish Wikipedia articles about them, returning both the person’s entity and the article title.

context: Timeline of Dietary Advocates
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of notable diet food advocates by combining data from DBpedia and Wikidata. It first selects individuals categorized as "Diet food advocates" in DBpedia, then matches them to their Wikidata entries. From Wikidata, it fetches their birth dates (from year 500 onwards), images, English labels, and descriptions. The results enable visualizing these advocates over time with relevant details.

context: Philosophers born between 0 and 500 grouped by the decade where they lived
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct philosophers born between years 100 and 500 AD, focusing on their birth and death dates, images, and countries. It groups them by decade, century, and millennium of birth, extracting labels and descriptions for better readability. The query also fetches optional details like portraits and nationality, providing a rich dataset for historical analysis.

context: Video games from ?country
target: This SPARQL query retrieves video games related to a specific country (here, Germany, wd:Q40). It finds games either made in that country or developed by studios based there. For each game, it lists the title, developers, publisher, and genres, grouping multiple developers and genres into comma-separated lists. Labels are shown in the user’s language or English.

context: Politicians with an account at GitHub, CPAN, or Wikimedia
target: This SPARQL query retrieves politicians (humans) who have an online presence on GitHub, CPAN, or Wikimedia. It identifies individuals classified as ministers—either by occupation or position held—and fetches their names, countries, and corresponding account identifiers on these platforms. Labels are included for readability in the preferred language.

query:
#defaultView:LineChart
SELECT ?decade
(100*SUM(?tuberculosiscount)/COUNT(?decade) AS ?percentage_of_deaths_cause_by_tuberculosis)
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P509 ?causeofdeath.
  ?item wdt:P570 ?sterbedatum.
  BIND(CONCAT(SUBSTR(CONCAT(STR(YEAR(?sterbedatum))),0,4),"0") as ?decade).
  FILTER( ?sterbedatum >= "1750-01-01T00:00:00"^^xsd:dateTime )
  FILTER( ?sterbedatum <= "2019-12-31T00:00:00"^^xsd:dateTime )
    BIND(
    IF(?causeofdeath = wd:Q12204,1,0)
    AS ?tuberculosiscount). 
}
GROUP BY ?decade #?ref
ORDER BY ?decade
context: Percentage of deaths caused by tuberculosis by decade
target: This SPARQL query calculates the percentage of deaths caused by tuberculosis for each decade between 1750 and 2019. It groups death records by decade, identifies if tuberculosis was the cause of death (counting it as 1 if true, otherwise 0), then computes the percentage by dividing the sum of tuberculosis deaths by the total deaths per decade, multiplying by 100. The results are ordered chronologically for visualization.

context: Number of programming languages and their paradigms
target: This SPARQL query retrieves programming languages from Wikidata and groups them by their programming paradigm. It counts how many languages belong to each paradigm, like object-oriented or functional. The query returns the paradigm's label and the corresponding count, enabling visualization of the distribution of programming languages across different paradigms.

context: Museums within 2 miles of MoMA
target: This SPARQL query finds museums located within about 2 miles (3.21869 kilometers) of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York City. It retrieves each museum’s name, image (if available), coordinates, and distance from MoMA in miles. Results are sorted by proximity, helping identify nearby museums for visitors or researchers.

context: Largest cities of the world ordered by population
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the 100 largest cities worldwide by population from Wikidata. It selects entities classified as cities (wd:Q515), fetching their population (wdt:P1082) and geographic coordinates (wdt:P625). The city names are returned in Spanish using the Wikibase label service. Results are ordered descendingly by population to list the biggest cities first.

context: Italian politicians who served as a minister in more than one cabinet since 1990
target: This SPARQL query finds Italian politicians who have served as ministers in more than one government cabinet since 1990. It looks for people with multiple ministerial positions (P39) linked to different cabinets (P5054) starting from 1990 onward. The query returns each politician’s name, the cabinets they served in, and includes some styling info for visualization.

context: People born after 1800 whose “name in native language” is in Latin
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct people (instances of humans) born on or after the year 1800 whose native names are recorded in Latin. For each person, it fetches their Wikidata entity, label (name), description, and native name in Latin. It uses language filtering to ensure the native name is specifically in Latin and includes labels in the user's preferred language or English.

context: UK statues and whether they are of nobles and/or women
target: This SPARQL query retrieves statues located in the UK and identifies the people they depict, focusing on whether these individuals are women and/or hold noble titles. It gathers each statue’s label, location, and image, along with the person’s name. The query then labels each person as "female" or "not female" and "has noble title" or "has no noble title," enabling analysis of gender and nobility representation in UK statues.

query:
#defaultView:Map
SELECT DISTINCT ?city ?cityLabel ?population ?location ?lon ?lat WHERE {
  # get cities (or classes based on city) in germany
  ?city wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q515 ;
        wdt:P17 wd:Q183 .
  
  # get population and location of the city
  ?city wdt:P1082 ?population ;
        wdt:P625 ?location .
  
  # we're only interested in cities with a population count > 50.000
  FILTER (abs(?population) > 50000)
  
  # extract lat and lon
  ?city p:P625 ?coordinate.
  ?coordinate psv:P625 ?coordinate_node.
  ?coordinate_node wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon.
  ?coordinate_node wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat. 
  
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],de,en" }
}
context: Location of German cities with a population count greater than 50.000
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct German cities (or city classes) with populations over 50,000. For each city, it fetches the city’s name, population, geographic coordinates, and extracts latitude and longitude separately. The results are labeled in the user’s preferred language and can be visualized on a map, showing major German urban centers by location and size.

query:
#added before 2016-10
#defaultView:Graph
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel ?rgb ?link ?link2
WHERE
{
  VALUES ?toggle { true false }
  ?disease wdt:P699 ?doid;
           wdt:P279* wd:Q18123741;
           wdt:P2176 ?drug.
  ?drug wdt:P3780 ?active.
  ?drug rdfs:label ?drugLabel.
		FILTER(LANG(?drugLabel) = "en").
  ?disease rdfs:label ?diseaseLabel.
		FILTER(LANG(?diseaseLabel) = "eu").
  BIND(IF(?toggle,?disease,?drug) AS ?item).
  BIND(IF(?toggle,?diseaseLabel,?drugLabel) AS ?itemLabel).
  BIND(IF(?toggle,"FFA500","7FFF00") AS ?rgb).
  BIND(IF(?toggle,"",?disease) AS ?link).
}
context: Map of medicines used (green) to fight infectious diseases (orange)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of infectious diseases and their associated drugs, focusing on diseases labeled in Basque and drugs labeled in English. It selects each disease and its drugs, assigning orange color (FFA500) to diseases and green (7FFF00) to drugs. The query also prepares links from drugs back to diseases, enabling a visual map of medicines (green) used to treat infectious diseases (orange).

context: Russian cuisine
target: This SPARQL query retrieves items that are parts of Russian cuisine (wd:Q12505) and have an associated image (property wdt:P18). For each item, it fetches the item’s identifier, its label in the user’s language or English, and the image URL. The default view displays results as an image grid, ideal for visually exploring components of Russian cuisine.

query:
SELECT ?name ?nameLabel ?dod ?image (GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT ?occupationLabel;separator=", ") AS ?occupations) (GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT ?countryLabel;separator=", ") AS ?countries)  WHERE {
  ?name wdt:P27 wd:Q31 .
  ?name wdt:P27 ?country .
  ?name wdt:P570 ?dod .
  ?name wdt:P106/wdt:P279* wd:Q483501 .
  ?name wdt:P106 ?occupation .
  OPTIONAL {?name wdt:P18 ?image} .
  FILTER (YEAR(?dod) = 1950)  .
SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en".
                       ?occupation rdfs:label ?occupationLabel .
                       ?country rdfs:label ?countryLabel .
                       ?name rdfs:label ?nameLabel .}
}
GROUP BY ?name ?dod ?image ?nameLabel
context: Belgian artists that rise to the public domain in 2021
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Belgian artists who died in 1950, making their works enter the public domain in 2021. For each artist, it fetches their name, date of death, image (if available), and lists their occupations and countries associated with them. Labels are provided in the user's language or English for readability.

context: Bubble diagram by wiki page numbers in each language on objects kept at the Bardo National Museum (note: Commons is counted as English)
target: This SPARQL query counts Wikipedia pages about objects housed at the Bardo National Museum, grouped by language. It finds pages linked to museum items (using property chains to identify these objects), then groups and counts them by the language of the page. The result is ideal for a bubble chart showing how many pages exist per language, with Commons counted as English.

context: Amusement parks around the world
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about amusement parks (items classified under Q194195 or its subclasses). It constructs triples linking each park to its type, English title, geographic coordinates (if available), and an image (if available). The query uses Wikidata’s label service to fetch English labels, providing a rich dataset of amusement parks worldwide with location and visual info.

context: All stumbling stones in the city of Hannover
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all "Stolpersteine" (stumbling stones) located in Hannover. For each stone, it fetches its identifier, label (name), geographic coordinates, and an image. The query filters items classified as stumbling stones (wd:Q26703203) and located in Hannover (wd:Q1715), then orders the results alphabetically by their label.

context: Web & social media URLs for UK Civic Societies
target: This SPARQL query retrieves UK civic societies (instances of Q5124370 located in the UK) along with their names and web presence. It fetches each society’s official website URL plus optional social media links for Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram by constructing full URLs from their usernames. The results are labeled in the user’s language and sorted alphabetically by name.

query:
#Accused witches in Scotland and the ritual objects they are said to have used
#defaultView:Map
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel ?accusedurl ?coords ?residenceLabel ?image (?ritual as ?layer) 
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q5.
  ?item wdt:P4478 ?accused .
  wd:P4478 wdt:P1630 ?formatterurl .
  BIND(IRI(REPLACE(?accused, '^(.+)$', ?formatterurl)) AS ?accusedurl).
  ?item wdt:P551 ?residence .
  ?residence wdt:P625 ?coords.
  ?item wdt:P8706 ?RitualObject . 
  OPTIONAL { ?RitualObject wdt:P18 ?image } 
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en".  
                  
                          ?charge rdfs:label ?chargeLabel .
                          ?RitualObject rdfs:label ?ritual .
                          ?residence rdfs:label ?residenceLabel .
                          ?item rdfs:label ?itemLabel .
                          ?accused rdfs:label ?accusedLabel .}
}
context: Map of the ritual objects said to be used by accused witches in Scotland (colourcoded layer accessible on top right to see the list of objects)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about accused witches in Scotland, focusing on the ritual objects they were said to have used. It selects each person (?item), their residence location with coordinates, and associated ritual objects, including images if available. The results include URLs for detailed info and labels for easy reading, enabling a map visualization with color-coded layers of ritual objects.

context: Seats of the Parliament of England, and the first year we have a named person listed for them
target: This SPARQL query retrieves members of the English Parliament (MPs) along with their parliamentary seats and the year they first held those seats. It focuses on terms classified under a specific parliamentary role (Q18018860) and finds the earliest start date for each seat. The results list MPs, their seats, and the first year a named person represented each seat, ordered by year, seat, and MP name.

context: Female race car drivers on Spanish Wikipedia
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 500 distinct male race car drivers (`wdt:P106 wd:Q10349745` for profession and `wdt:P21 wd:Q6581072` for male gender) who have articles on Spanish Wikipedia. It selects each driver's Wikidata item (`?auto`) along with the Spanish Wikipedia page title (`?auto_pag`). Despite the context mentioning female drivers, the query filters for males.

context: Places of Geological Interest in Alamedilla
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 geological sites located in Alamedilla (a municipality). For each site, it fetches its name, coordinates (if available), and an image (if available). The query uses Wikidata properties to filter places within Alamedilla (wdt:P131) that are classified as geological sites (wdt:P31). Labels are returned in the user's language or English.

context: Number of Nature articles that were published on a Sunday in a given year
target: This SPARQL query counts how many articles published in the journal *Nature* (wdt:P1433 wd:Q180445) were released on Sundays each year. It extracts the publication date (?date) of each article (?i), calculates the number of weeks between that date and December 6, 2020, and filters for dates exactly a whole number of weeks apart—indicating Sundays. Finally, it groups the counts by publication year (?year).

context: Tex-Mex singers
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 distinct humans who are Tex-Mex singers. It filters for humans (`wdt:P31 wd:Q5`) with professions (`wdt:P106`) matching singer, musician, or composer (`wd:Q177220`, `wd:Q639669`, `wd:Q488205`), and whose music genre (`wdt:P136`) is Tex-Mex (`wd:Q431415`). The query also fetches their English labels for easy reading.

context: Map of images from Wicipics project (photography campaign in Wales)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a distinct list of items related to the Wicipics photography project in Wales (identified by property P5008 with value Q101553389). For each item, it fetches its coordinates (P625), image (P18), type (P31), and labels/descriptions in Welsh or English. The results can be visualized on a map layer labeled by item type.

context: Vito Russo Test in Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves films from Wikidata evaluated by the Vito Russo Test, which measures LGBTQIA+ representation. For each film, it lists the title, earliest release year, production countries, test result ("passing" or "failing"), score, and description of the test criteria. It groups data by film and orders results by year, helping analyze LGBTQIA+ visibility over time.

context: Distinct dialects of Wikidata lexemes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct languages (dialects) used in Wikidata lexemes and counts how many unique lexemes each language has. It filters languages that are instances of "language" (Q33384), then orders the results by the number of lexemes in descending order. Labels are included for readability, making it ideal for visualizing language distribution in lexemes.

query:
SELECT ?metro ?metroLabel ?locationLabel ?clientelaLabel
WHERE {
  ?metro wdt:P31 wd:Q5503.
  ?metro wdt:P131 ?location .
  ?metro wdt:P3872 ?clientela .
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "es,en". } }
order by ?clientela
limit 200
context: Patronage of rapid-transit transportation
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 200 metro systems (wd:Q5503) along with their locations and types of patronage (clientela). It fetches each metro’s name, the place it’s located in, and the nature of its ridership, displaying labels in Spanish or English. Results are ordered by the patronage type, helping analyze rapid-transit usage patterns.

context: People who played Julius Caesar, and what "version" of him they played
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct actors who played Julius Caesar or characters based on him in various works (like movies or plays). It identifies the specific "version" of Caesar portrayed, such as adaptations or inspired roles. The query also fetches the publication or release date of each work, along with labels and descriptions, providing a clear overview of different portrayals of Caesar across media.

context: Works identified (via dedicated property P3893) as entering the public domain on 1/1/2021, ordered by number of articles on Wikimedia sites
target: This SPARQL query retrieves works that entered the public domain in 2021, identified by the property P3893 (public domain date). For each work, it fetches its label, type, the exact date it became public domain, and the number of Wikimedia site articles about it. Results are ordered by descending article count, highlighting the most documented works.

context: Painters in the collections of Paris Musées which enter the public domain on January 1
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct paintings from the Paris Musées collections created by artists who died in 1950, meaning their works entered the public domain on January 1 following that year. It lists each artwork with its title, artist, museum, creation date, and optionally its inventory number, sorting results by artist name. Labels are shown in French or English.

context: Map of forts related to Dutch trading companies VOC and WIC
target: This SPARQL query retrieves forts linked to Dutch trading companies (VOC and WIC) from Wikidata. It selects items classified under forts (wd:Q57821) or their subclasses, fetching their names, geographic coordinates, and URLs. It filters results to include only those with URLs containing "atlasofmutualheritage," providing mapped locations and references for these historic sites.

context: Map of forts in the Cologne fortress ring
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about forts that are part of the Cologne fortress ring (identified by wd:Q1409040). For each fort, it fetches its coordinates, type, label (name), optional image, and inception date. The query also uses the Wikibase label service to get labels in the user's language or German, enabling a map visualization of these forts with relevant details.

query:
# Query to get first level administrative region of a country
SELECT DISTINCT ?region ?regionLabel ?pop ?ended
WHERE {
  # Instance of first administrative division
  ?region p:P31 ?stat.
  ?stat a wikibase:BestRank.
  FILTER NOT EXISTS { ?stat pq:P582 []}
  ?stat ps:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q10864048.
  
#  ?region wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q10864048.
  #UNION { ?city wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q515. }

  ?region wdt:P1082 ?pop.
  ?region wdt:P150 ?regionContained.
      
  # only in Germany
  ?region wdt:P17 wd:Q183.
  
  MINUS { ?region wdt:P576 ?x. } # remove region that has been disolved
  # remove region that is nowdays not a first level administrative region
  
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en" }
}
ORDER BY DESC(?pop)
context: First-level administrative divisions in Germany
target: This SPARQL query retrieves first-level administrative regions (like states) within Germany. It selects regions that are current (not dissolved), verified as first-level divisions, and belong to Germany (country code Q183). For each region, it fetches its name, population, and dissolution date if any. Results are ordered by population in descending order, highlighting the most populous regions first.

context: Population of cities in Germany corresponds to the total number of vaccinations in Germany
target: This SPARQL query retrieves German cities with populations close to 41,962, reflecting vaccination totals in Germany. It selects distinct cities (`?city`) classified as cities (`wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q486972`), located in Germany (`wdt:P17 wd:Q183`), and having a population (`wdt:P1082`) within ±100 of 41,962. Labels are returned in the user’s language or Dutch.

context: Most popular theorems according to their number of articles on Wikipedia
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 100 mathematical theorems ranked by their popularity on Wikipedia. It selects each theorem (and its label), counts how many distinct Wikipedia articles mention it, and also fetches the total number of sitelinks (links to the theorem’s page across Wikimedia projects). The results are grouped by theorem and ordered by the number of related Wikipedia articles in descending order, highlighting the most referenced theorems.

context: Number of people who have died, or been diagnosed, of COVID-19, grouped by occupation
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of occupations along with the count of distinct people associated with each occupation who either died from or were diagnosed with COVID-19. It groups individuals by their occupation and orders the results to show the occupations with the highest number of affected people first, providing insight into COVID-19’s impact across different professions.

context: Deaths in 2020 - date of birth, date of death, cause of death and country of nationality
target: This SPARQL query counts the number of distinct humans (wd:Q5) who died in the year 2020. It filters items with a recorded date of death (wdt:P570) between January 1, 2020, and January 1, 2021. Essentially, it returns the total number of people who passed away during 2020, based on Wikidata entries.

context: Summary of a UK parliamentary career seat-party-start pairs
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct periods during which a specified UK Member of Parliament (MP) held a seat, detailing the party and constituency for each term. It pairs each term’s start and end dates, calculates the duration in days, and formats a summary string showing the constituency, party, and years served. It excludes overlapping or untaken seats to ensure clean, continuous service records.

context: Timeline of aircraft types around the world and the first time a type of aircraft made a flight
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 500 aircraft types (instances or subclasses of "aircraft") from Wikidata, along with their labels, first flight dates, and images. It filters for aircraft with a first flight year of 1903 or later, extracting the year separately. The results support a timeline view showing when different aircraft types first flew worldwide.

context: Indonesian legislation related to indigenous people
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Indonesian laws related to indigenous peoples. It selects legal documents (?hukum) tagged with the topic "indigenous peoples" (Q2986880) and classified as a type of legislation (Q12504878). For each law, it fetches the associated region (?daerah), its label, and geographic coordinates (?koord). Labels are returned in Indonesian.

query:
# search for artist D.K. active in 1964
# Source: https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property_talk:P7457#Related_queries:_Who_could_be_%22J.B._1670%22_and_%22D.K._1964%22?
# query by Jura1, 2021-01-02, suggestion by https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/User:Herzi_Pinki

SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?d1 ?d2 ?nl0 ?nl1 ?itemDescription ?sig 
WHERE
{
    ?item wdt:P569 ?d1 ; wdt:P570 ?d2 .
    hint:Prior hint:rangeSafe true .
    FILTER( ?d1 > "1880-00-00"^^xsd:dateTime &&
            ?d2 > "1964-00-00"^^xsd:dateTime &&
            ?d1 < "1944-00-00"^^xsd:dateTime
          )
    ?item wdt:P735 / wdt:P1705 ?nl0 . FILTER( REGEX(?nl0, "^D" ) )
    ?item wdt:P734 / wdt:P1705 ?nl1 . FILTER( REGEX(?nl1, "^K" ) )
    ?item wdt:P106/wdt:P279* wd:Q3391743 .
     hint:Prior hint:gearing "forward".   
    OPTIONAL { ?item wdt:P109 ?sig }
    SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en" }
}
context: Which artist could be "D.K. 1964"?
target: This SPARQL query searches Wikidata for artists potentially matching the mysterious signature "D.K. 1964." It looks for individuals born between 1880 and 1944 and who died after 1964. Their first name starts with "D" and last name starts with "K." The query ensures the person is an artist (or subclass thereof) and optionally retrieves their signature. It helps identify who "D.K. 1964" might be.

context: Line graph of colleges and universities in India by year of establishment
target: This SPARQL query counts the number of colleges and universities in India established each year. It selects items with the property P6392 (indicating Indian higher education institutions) and their inception date (P571). It extracts the year from each date, groups the institutions by year, and returns the count per year. The results can be visualized as a line chart showing growth over time.

context: Graph of Indian films that are remakes of other Indian films
target: This SPARQL query retrieves pairs of Indian films where one is a remake of the other. It selects films (?i) and their originals (?j), both instances of "film" (Q11424) produced in India (Q668). The query uses the property P144 (based on) in reverse to find films (?i) that are remakes of other Indian films (?j), returning their labels for easy reading.

context: Graph of academic descendants of C. R. Rao and K. Ananda Rau
target: This SPARQL query retrieves academics (?i) who studied at institutions (?place1) linked to the birthplaces of C. R. Rao (Q711237) or K. Ananda Rau (Q11115439) and have academic advisors (?j) connected through a chain of mentorships (?j wdt:P184* ?source). It also fetches labels and images for these individuals, showing a graph of their academic lineage rooted in these two scholars.

context: Map of gram panchayats in Kerala by literacy rate in 2001
target: This SPARQL query fetches gram panchayats in Kerala (entities of type Q2732840) along with their shapes and literacy rates recorded after January 1, 2001. It assigns a color code (?rgb) based on literacy rate thresholds to visualize data on a map. Labels are retrieved in English and Malayalam for user-friendly display.

context: Maps of different places in West Bengal according to suffix
target: This SPARQL query retrieves places within the administrative region identified by wd:Q1356 (West Bengal) that have geographic coordinates (wdt:P625) and an associated label in English. It filters for places whose names end with specific suffixes like "abad," "pukur," or "bazar," representing common place-name endings in West Bengal. The results include the place, its label, the matched suffix (layer), and coordinates, useful for mapping these culturally significant locations.

context: Tree map of Rabindranath's poems according to the month of writing
target: This SPARQL query retrieves poems written by Rabindranath Tagore, focusing on those created after 1936. For each poem, it extracts the creation date, then derives the month and year, combining them into a "month-year" label. The query also fetches the poem's label in Bengali or English, enabling a tree map visualization grouped by writing month.

context: Count of locations of exhibitions on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query counts how many exhibitions are held at each location, using data from Wikidata. It finds items classified as exhibitions (wd:Q464980 or its subclasses) and retrieves their associated locations. The query then groups results by location, fetching labels in Dutch, and orders them by the number of exhibitions, showing the most popular venues first.

context: Wikidata lexeme forms by language
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of lexeme forms available for each language in Wikidata. It counts all lexical forms linked to lexemes, groups them by language, and then orders the results from the most to the least forms. The query also fetches the language names in English for easy readability, making it ideal for visualizing language coverage in lexeme data.

context: Mathematicians born in prime number years featuring Albert Einstein, Pierre de Fermat, Georg Ohm, Carl Gauss, Évariste Galois, Augustin-Louis Cauchy, James Maxwell et al.
target: This SPARQL query finds mathematicians born in years that are prime numbers less than 2021. First, it gathers all such prime years and concatenates them into a string. Then, it selects people whose occupation is mathematician and whose birth year matches one of these prime years. Finally, it orders the results by the number of Wikipedia sitelinks, highlighting notable figures like Einstein and Gauss.

context: Timeline of coups d'état of the 21st century
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of coups d'état from the 21st century onward. It selects each coup event (?coup) and its label, finds the earliest associated date (?date_), and optionally includes an image (?image_). The query filters events dated between 2001 and 2100, grouping results by coup to provide a concise, date-ordered overview with labels and visuals when available.

query:
#Children of which were born with by a person, and their step child.
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?parentLabel ?spousesChildLabel
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q5.
  ?parent wdt:P40 ?item.
  ?parent wdt:P26 ?spouse.
  ?spouse wdt:P40 ?spousesChild .
  ?spousesChild wdt:P40 ?item. 
      
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
}
context: Children of which were born with by a person, and their step child
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people (?item) who have biological children (?parent) and are married (?parent wdt:P26 ?spouse) to someone (?spouse) who also has children (?spousesChild). It then finds cases where the original person (?item) is also a parent of the spouse’s child, indicating a blended family where the person is both a biological parent and a step-parent. Labels for all entities are included for readability.

context: Map of the shortest railway path (in terms of number of stations) between Dibrugarh and the Scottish Highlands
target: This SPARQL query finds the shortest railway path between Dibrugarh (India) and the Scottish Highlands by using a breadth-first search algorithm over railway station data in Wikidata. It retrieves each station on this path, excluding the start, along with geographic coordinates. The query then constructs line segments connecting consecutive stations, enabling visualization of the route on a map with labels in English.

context: Map of place of birth of Olympique de Marseille football players
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about football players (humans with the occupation "footballer") who have played for Olympique de Marseille (club ID Q2378143). It fetches each player's name, birth date, place of birth with geographic coordinates, and image if available. The results can be visualized on a map showing where these players were born.

context: Map of Kolkata wards by number of schools
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all wards within Kolkata, counting the number of schools in each ward. It selects wards that belong to Kolkata and have a defined geographical shape. Based on the school count, it assigns a color code (RGB) to each ward to visualize density on a map, where darker greens indicate more schools. The query also fetches ward labels for display.

context: Map of beaches in Mexico
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a distinct list of beaches located in Mexico. It selects each beach’s identifier (?beach), its label (?beachLabel) in Spanish or English, and its geographic coordinates (?coord). The query filters entities that are instances of beaches (wd:Q40080) within Mexico (wd:Q96), enabling visualization of these locations on a map.

context: Graph of shared borders between Indian districts
target: This SPARQL query retrieves pairs of Indian districts that share a border. It selects entities (?i and ?j) classified as districts (wd:Q1149652) and connected by the "shares border with" property (wdt:P47). The query also fetches their labels in the user's language or English, enabling visualization of the graph of neighboring districts in India.

context: Descendants of Upendrakishore Roy
target: This SPARQL query finds descendants of Upendrakishore Roy (wd:Q737942) by traversing the family tree forward through child relationships (wdt:P40) up to 15 generations. It returns each descendant’s item ID, labels in Bengali and English, an image if available (wdt:P18), and a direct child link. The query uses Blazegraph’s graph analytics service for efficient shortest path traversal.

context: Timeline of Indian High Commissioners to Britain
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of Indian High Commissioners to Britain. It selects each commissioner’s item (?i), their label (?iLabel), an image (?img), and their term start (?p580) and end dates (?p582). If the end date is missing, it uses the current date. The query also fetches labels in the user’s language and includes images when available, enabling a visual timeline view.

context: A tree map of items for artworks depicting Mughal emperors
target: This SPARQL query retrieves artworks (paintings) that depict Mughal emperors and are held in collections located in India. It selects each emperor (?item) who served as a Mughal emperor, the paintings (?painting) portraying them, and their respective labels. The results enable visualizing these artworks in a tree map, organized by emperor and painting.

context: Example of documented usage of different Bengali words
target: This SPARQL query retrieves documented usage examples of Bengali words (lexemes). For each lexeme in Bengali, it fetches example sentences, optional word forms, and sense definitions in Bengali. It also gathers source references for each example. Results are grouped by lexeme and example, with labels provided in Bengali or English, ordered by lexeme for easy browsing.

context: 'Llan' place names in the UK
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct places in the United Kingdom (wd:Q145) whose English labels start with "Llan." For each matching place, it fetches the item’s identifier, its English label, and geographic coordinates (P625). The query ensures labels are in English and uses Wikibase services to handle language-specific labels, ideal for mapping "Llan"-named locations in the UK.

query:
# Organisationen nach Spenden
SELECT ?Orga ?Organisation ?Spenden (YEAR(?Spenden_Zeit) AS ?Bezugsjahr)
WHERE 
{
  ?Orga wdt:P166 wd:Q62019748 . # gGmbH
  
  ?Orga p:P8093 ?Spenden_statement . # Statement Spenden
  ?Spenden_statement psv:P8093 ?Spenden_Wert . # Wert Spenden
  ?Spenden_Wert wikibase:quantityAmount ?Spenden . # Summe Spenden
  ?Spenden_statement pq:P585 ?Spenden_Zeit . # Zeitpunk Spenden
  FILTER NOT EXISTS # Nur neuesten Wert herausfiltern
  {
    ?Orga p:P8093/pq:P585 ?Spenden_Zeit2 .
    FILTER(?Spenden_Zeit2 > ?Spenden_Zeit)
  }
  
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "de,en". ?Orga rdfs:label ?Organisation . } # OrgaLabel umbennen
}

ORDER BY DESC(?Spenden) # Sortieren nach höchstem Spenden
context: Organizations with DZI donation seal approval according to donation amount
target: This SPARQL query retrieves organizations labeled as gGmbH (non-profit companies) that have received donations, identified by the DZI donation seal (wd:Q62019748). For each organization, it fetches the latest donation amount and the year it was recorded. Results are sorted by donation size in descending order, showing the top donors with their names, donation sums, and corresponding years.

context: Red Cross and Red Crescent societies
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about Red Cross and Red Crescent societies (entities classified as Q1968122). For each society, it fetches labels, descriptions, founding and end dates, country and its population, website, Twitter handle, Facebook ID, and metadata like statement, identifier, and sitelink counts. Results are grouped by country and society, ordered by country name, end date, population, and society name.

context: The people of the government of Bangladesh on 13 January 2005
target: This SPARQL query retrieves government officials of Bangladesh holding positions on January 13, 2005. It selects individuals (?i) with roles (?pos) linked to Bangladesh (country code Q902), active on that date based on start (?start) and end (?end) times. It also optionally fetches associated constituencies (?const). Labels are returned in Bengali and English, ordered by position and constituency names.

context: Buildings in the Basque Country dedicated to San Roque
target: This SPARQL query retrieves buildings related to San Roque (wd:Q152457) located within the Basque Country (wd:Q47588). It looks for items that either are located in or are parts of entities within the Basque Country. For each building, it fetches its label and optionally its geographic coordinates (P625). The results can be visualized on a map.

context: List of words for "beard" in Eighth Schedule languages
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the lemmas (words) for "beard" (wd:Q42804) in the languages listed as part of India’s Eighth Schedule (wd:Q12414903). It finds lexemes linked to the concept "beard," filters them by languages included in the Eighth Schedule, and returns each language’s label along with the corresponding word. Labels are shown in the user’s language or English.

context: Map of train services starting at Howrah station
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct train lines connecting stations within India, focusing on routes starting from Howrah station. It first selects stations classified as railway stations (excluding certain types), with their geographic coordinates. Then, it constructs line geometries (LINESTRING) representing connections between stations and their neighboring stops. Finally, it fetches labels in Bengali and English for these connections, enabling a map visualization of train routes originating at Howrah.

context: Map of big sculptures of New Zealand
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of big sculptures in New Zealand from Wikidata. For each sculpture (?item), it fetches its English label (?label), an image (?_image) if available, and geographic coordinates (?coordinate_location) when provided. The results can be visualized on a map, highlighting these notable sculptures across New Zealand.

context: Map of mosques in Bangladesh according to architectural style
target: This SPARQL query retrieves mosques located in Bangladesh, including their coordinates and architectural styles. It selects items classified as mosques (Q32815) within Bangladesh (Q902), fetching their geographic coordinates (P625) and architectural type (P149). Labels for mosques and styles are returned in Bengali and English, enabling a map visualization by style.

context: UK deaths per month since 2005 split by sex/gender
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of deaths in the UK per month since 2005, grouped by gender. It selects humans (wd:Q5) with UK citizenship (wd:Q145), filters death dates with at least month-level precision, and extracts the year and month of death. The results show monthly death counts split by gender, useful for visualizing trends over time with a scatter chart.

context: Timeline of Indian cricket tours abroad
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Indian cricket tours abroad, specifically international cricket series (wd:Q50846468) in the sport of cricket (wd:Q5375), involving the Indian cricket team (wd:Q1143793). It fetches each tour’s start (P580) and end (P582) dates, excluding those held in India (wd:Q668). The results include tour names with English labels, ideal for creating a timeline view.

context: Timeline of inception of Mexican universities
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of Mexican universities by selecting each university’s entity, its label (name), and its founding date. It filters entities located in Mexico (wd:Q96) that are classified as universities (wd:Q3918) and have an inception date (wdt:P571). Labels are returned in Spanish or English for readability.

context: Mangifera species and mango cultivars
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct mango species and cultivars from Wikidata. It selects each item's identifier, Indonesian label (name), description, and optionally an image. The query combines two groups: items classified as descendants of the Mangifera genus (Q161807) and items identified as mango cultivars (Q27068180). Results are shown with Indonesian labels and descriptions.

query:
#defaultView:Map
SELECT * WHERE {
   wd:Q104863295 p:P276 ?stat . 
    ?stat ps:P276 ?location .
    ?location p:P625 [ ps:P625 [];  psv:P625 [ wikibase:geoLongitude ?coord1lon; wikibase:geoLatitude ?coord1lat; ] ].
   ?stat pq:P1545 ?series .
  
   wd:Q104863295 p:P276 ?stat2 . 
    ?stat2 ps:P276 ?location2 .
    ?location2 p:P625 [ ps:P625 [];  psv:P625 [ wikibase:geoLongitude ?coord2lon; wikibase:geoLatitude ?coord2lat; ] ].
   ?stat2 pq:P1545 ?series2 .
  
  filter (xsd:integer(?series) = xsd:integer(?series2) -1)
  
  BIND(CONCAT('LINESTRING (', STR(?coord1lon), ' ', STR(?coord1lat), ',', STR(?coord2lon), ' ', STR(?coord2lat), ')') AS ?str) .
  BIND(STRDT(?str, geo:wktLiteral) AS ?line) 
    BIND("ff0033" as ?rgb)
   BIND("voyage" AS ?layer) 
}
context: Locations where The Antartic Circumpolar Voyage expedition passed
target: This SPARQL query retrieves consecutive locations visited during the Antarctic Circumpolar Voyage expedition (wd:Q104863295). It pairs each location with the next one in the visit sequence, extracts their geographic coordinates, and constructs a LINESTRING representing the path segment between them. The query also assigns styling info for map visualization, enabling a connected route display of the voyage.

context: English Language forms missing an audio pronunciation
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all distinct English lexical entries (lemmas) that currently lack an audio pronunciation. It excludes affixes by filtering out entries categorized as such. Specifically, it selects lexical items with English language tags and their lemmas, ensures the form matches the lemma, and filters out any forms that already have an audio file linked, helping identify words needing pronunciation recordings.

context: Czech religious buildings used also as a fire station
target: This SPARQL query retrieves items that are instances of both Czech religious buildings (Q1195942) and subclasses of fire stations (Q24398318). For each item, it fetches the label and an optional image if available. Essentially, it lists Czech religious buildings that have also served as fire stations, showing their names and pictures in an image grid.

context: Common ingredients to prepare a sandwich
target: This SPARQL query retrieves and counts common ingredients used in sandwiches from Wikidata. It selects items classified as sandwiches (wd:Q28803) or their subclasses, then finds their components (ingredients). The query groups these ingredients by name and orders them by frequency, showing which ingredients appear most often in sandwich recipes. Results are labeled in Spanish or English.

context: Location of GLAMs with open access policies
target: This SPARQL query retrieves cultural institutions (GLAMs) that have open access policies, identified by the property P1343 linked to a specific policy item (Q73357989). For each institution, it fetches the name, geographic coordinates—either directly or via headquarters location—and an image if available. Labels are returned in the user's language or English.

context: Mexican presidents who have an image of their signature on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Mexican presidents who have their signature images stored in Wikidata. It selects distinct presidents (?presidente) holding the office of President of Mexico (wd:Q628004) and fetches their signature images (?firma). Labels are returned in Spanish for easier reading. The default view displays results as an image grid.

context: Timeline of Mexican writers who were born between 1800 and 1900
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of Mexican writers born in the 19th century. It selects distinct items classified as writers (occupation P106 = writer Q36180) with Mexican nationality (P27 = Mexico Q96), including their birth (P569) and death (P570) dates. The query filters for those born between 1800 and 1900 and fetches labels and descriptions in Spanish or English for display.

context: TV-Series in Spain by Decade
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of distinct TV series produced in Spain, including details like their start and end dates, original broadcaster, number of episodes, duration, and seasons. It also fetches descriptions, labels in Spanish or English, and the number of Wikipedia sitelinks. The results are ordered by the most recent start date, helping analyze Spanish TV series by decade.

context: Diplomats who are also art collectors
target: This SPARQL query retrieves individuals who have two occupations: diplomat (wd:Q193391) and art collector (wd:Q10732476). It selects these people (?item) along with their labels (?itemLabel) in the preferred language. Essentially, it finds diplomats who are also art collectors by filtering entities with both job properties in Wikidata.

context: Basque lexemes and their attestations in a 1745 Spanish-Basque dictionary, with links to dictionary entries in Wikisource
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Basque lexemes from Wikidata linked to the 1745 Spanish-Basque dictionary by Larramendi. For each lexeme, it gets the standardized lemma, all attested forms recorded in the dictionary, the corresponding Spanish headwords, and URLs to the original Wikisource dictionary pages. Results are grouped by lemma and ordered by attested forms.

context: Lexemes describing a color
target: This SPARQL query retrieves lexemes (words or phrases) that describe colors from a Wikibase dataset. It selects each lexical entry’s identifier, its lemma (the canonical form of the word), and the language label. The query filters entries to those classified as color descriptions (instance of Q376431) and orders results by language for easy browsing across languages.

context: Danish-Hebrew Lexeme pairs
target: This SPARQL query retrieves unique pairs of Danish and Hebrew lexemes (words) linked by a shared sense. It selects Danish lexemes (`?lexeme`) with their lemmas (`?lemma`), then finds corresponding Hebrew lexemes (`?foreignlexeme`) and their lemmas (`?foreignlemma`). The query ensures the Danish lexemes are in Danish (language Q9035) and the foreign ones in Hebrew (Q9288), filtering Hebrew lemmas to Hebrew language tags.

context: Lexemes in Swedish with usage example that demonstrates both a form and a sense and a reference
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Swedish lexemes that have usage examples illustrating both a specific form and meaning, along with a source reference. It selects the lexeme ID, lemma (base form), example sentence, source label, and source item. The query ensures examples are linked to statements with qualifiers for form and sense, and includes provenance data for reliable sourcing.

context: Episodes of the TV series "The Mentalist"
target: This SPARQL query retrieves detailed information about episodes of the TV series *The Mentalist*. It selects each episode’s unique ID, label, original title, season number, episode number within the season, and overall episode number. It also fetches the season entity and metadata like the number of sitelinks and statements. Results are ordered by season and episode number for easy reading.

query:
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
SELECT DISTINCT 
?citizenship ?citizenship_label (COUNT(?citizenship_label) AS ?count) 
WHERE
{ ?work wdt:P6982 ?afd .
  
  
    ?work wdt:P50 ?author .
    ?author rdfs:label ?name .
    FILTER (lang(?name) = 'en')
     ?author wdt:P27 ?citizenship .
    ?citizenship rdfs:label ?citizenship_label .
    FILTER (lang(?citizenship_label) = 'en')    
   
   
}
GROUP BY ?citizenship ?citizenship_label
context: Nationality of authors publishing papers relevant to the Australian fauna
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the nationalities of authors who have published papers related to the Australian fauna, identified by the topic ID `wdt:P6982` (Australian fauna). It counts how many authors belong to each citizenship, returning distinct citizenships with their English labels and the number of authors per nationality. This helps analyze the diversity of contributors in this research area.

context: Number of musicians on Wikidata by country
target: This SPARQL query counts the number of musicians on Wikidata grouped by their citizenship. It selects entities classified as humans (wd:Q5) who have the occupation musician (wd:Q639669) and retrieves their citizenship (P27). The results show each country’s name alongside the total count of musicians, ordered from highest to lowest.

context: Map of ISO 3166-2 codes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves regions identified by their ISO 3166-2 codes, along with related data like their country, country ISO 3166-1 codes, labels, descriptions, and geographic coordinates if available. It links each region to its country and fetches labels in Swedish or English. The results are ordered by country name and region code, ideal for mapping regions by ISO codes.

context: Map films that have been filmed in Mexico
target: This SPARQL query retrieves films (instances of "film") that were shot in Mexico. It selects each film (?peli) along with its label, the filming location (?lugar) in Mexico, that location’s label, and its geographic coordinates (?coord). The query uses Wikidata properties to link films to their filming places and fetches labels in Spanish, enabling a map view of Mexican filming sites.

context: Map of Githubtopics on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves GitHub topics from Wikidata along with their geographic coordinates, descriptions, images, and related country information. It constructs URLs linking to GitHub topic pages and optionally fetches associated Wikipedia articles. The results are labeled and sorted by item name, enabling visualization of GitHub topics on a map with contextual details like images and descriptions.

context: Timeline with the start date of the Summer Olympics
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all instances of the Summer Olympics (wd:Q159821) along with their start dates (wdt:P580). It selects each event (?jo), its label in Spanish (?joLabel), and the start date (?date). The results can be used to create a timeline showing when each Summer Olympics began.

query:
SELECT
  ?director ?directorLabel ?directorDescription 
  (COUNT(?item) as ?count_episodes) 
  (SAMPLE(?item) as ?sample_episode)
  (SAMPLE(?original_title) as ?sample_title)
WHERE
{
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q21191270  ; wdt:P179 wd:Q204228 .
  ?item wdt:P57 ?director .
  OPTIONAL { ?item wdt:P1476 ?original_title }
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
}
GROUP BY ?director ?directorLabel ?directorDescription 
ORDER BY DESC(?count_episodes) ?directorLabel
context: directors of episodes of The Mentalist
target: This SPARQL query retrieves directors of episodes from the TV series *The Mentalist* (wd:Q204228). For each director, it lists their name and description, counts how many episodes they directed, and provides a sample episode and its original title. Results are grouped by director and sorted by the number of episodes directed, showing the most prolific directors first.

context: Articles from The Wētā entomology journal
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 1,000 scholarly articles published in *The Wētā* entomology journal. It selects items classified as scholarly articles (`wdt:P31 wd:Q13442814`) that have *The Wētā* (`wdt:P1433 wd:Q21385466`) as their publisher. The query also fetches article titles when available, using labels in the user's language or English.

context: Town halls of the municipalities that surround Nantes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct town halls located in the municipalities surrounding Nantes (Q12191). It selects each municipality (commune) that is an administrative territorial entity linked to Nantes as its central place. For these communes, it fetches town halls (or their subclasses), along with their labels, coordinates, and images if available. The results are ordered by the commune’s name.

context: Caves containing prehistoric art
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct prehistoric cave sites (wd:Q11269813) that have geographic coordinates (P625). For each cave, it fetches the site’s name in multiple languages and optionally includes an image (P18) if available. The results provide locations and visuals of caves known for prehistoric art, ideal for mapping or cultural studies.

context: Endemic birds in a place located in France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves birds that are endemic to places within France. It selects items classified as birds (descendants of the bird class), linked to specific locations (places) inside France. For each bird, it fetches its name, the place’s name, and optionally an image if available. Labels are returned in the user's language or English.

context: Websites related to works in the Women's & Gender History DH list
target: This SPARQL query retrieves items from Wikidata that are recognized as works included in the Women's & Gender History Digital Humanities list (identified by Q76510930). For each item, it fetches the item's label (name) in the user's language or English and, if available, its official website URL. The results are sorted alphabetically by the item label.

context: List of states with more than one official language
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of states (entities of type Q3624078) that have more than one official language (property P37). It selects distinct states linked to at least two different official languages, ensuring each pair is counted once by filtering language pairs alphabetically. The query also fetches state labels in the user's language or English, ordering results alphabetically.

context: Location of the organizations in the Name Assigning Authority Number (NAAN) registry
target: This SPARQL query retrieves organizations registered in the Name Assigning Authority Number (NAAN) registry, identified by their DOI prefix (wdt:P1662). For each organization, it fetches the geographic coordinates (wdt:P625) to map their location, optionally includes an image (wdt:P18), and provides their English labels. The results enable visualizing these entities on a map.

context: Use the MediaWiki API to get the content of a Wikipedia category into a query
target: This SPARQL query uses the MediaWiki API to fetch all articles from the Swedish Wikipedia category "Födda 2001" (Born in 2001). It then retrieves each article’s corresponding Wikidata item and queries the gender (property P21) associated with it. Finally, it returns the item, its label, and the gender label, adapting labels to the user’s language preferences.

context: Number of scholarly articles sharing their datasets
target: This SPARQL query counts scholarly articles (instances of Q13442814) that reference datasets (via property P1325) and have publication dates (P577). It extracts the publication year from each article’s date, groups the articles by year, and orders the results by the count of articles per year. The output shows yearly counts of articles sharing datasets.

context: Most specific taxon that includes two given species
target: This SPARQL query finds the most specific common ancestor taxon shared by two species: *Alocasia cuprea* and *Codiaeum variegatum*. It searches for a taxon that is an ancestor of both, but excludes any ancestor that has a more specific shared descendant, ensuring the result is the closest shared parent. The query also retrieves the taxon's rank, label, and an image if available.

context: List of vegan restaurants
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a distinct list of items labeled as vegan restaurants from Wikidata. It first selects entities classified under the vegan restaurant category (Q61960067), including any subclasses via property paths. Then, it fetches their labels in the user's language, providing a clear, human-readable list of vegan restaurants.

context: Map of monuments in Lower Saxony, Germany
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of monuments in Lower Saxony, Germany, identified by their Denkmalatlas IDs. For each monument, it fetches the label (name), geographic coordinates, an image if available, and links to both its Denkmalatlas metadata page and the corresponding German Wikipedia article. The results are designed for mapping, with coordinates optionally hidden.

context: Map of Wats in Thailand
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of Buddhist temples (wats) located in Thailand. It selects each temple’s unique identifier (?wat), its name (?watLabel), and geographic coordinates (?coord) if available. The query filters entities classified as Buddhist temples (wd:Q427287) within Thailand (wd:Q869) and orders the results alphabetically by their Thai or auto-detected labels, ideal for mapping these sites.

context: Localities in Mexico and contain 𝐒𝐚n in their name
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct localities in Mexico whose names start with "San" in Spanish. It selects entities classified as localities (wd:Q20202352) and filters their Spanish labels beginning with "San". The query also fetches their Spanish labels using Wikibase’s label service, ensuring results are user-friendly and language-specific.

context: Female mycologists born pre-1900, sorted by number of sitelinks
target: This SPARQL query retrieves female mycologists born before 1900 (or who died before 1920) from Wikidata. It selects each scientist’s name, birth/death dates, occupation label, and related identifiers like Harvard or Bloodhound IDs. The results include the number of Wikidata statements and Wikipedia sitelinks, sorted by sitelinks count to highlight notable figures with extensive coverage.

context: Women scientists who were born between the year 1500 and 1900
target: This SPARQL query retrieves women scientists born between 1500 and 1900. It selects each individual’s name, birth date, number of Wikipedia language links (articles), and concatenates their occupations and countries of citizenship.
