target: This SPARQL query retrieves all items that have won the Right Livelihood Award (property P166 with value Q152770). For each laureate, it fetches their English label (name) and optionally their image (property P18). The results display laureates’ names alongside their pictures, ideal for creating an image grid of award winners.

context: Chelsea FC players, with English Wikipedia article, Commons image, etc
target: This SPARQL query retrieves detailed information about Chelsea FC players from Wikidata. It lists each player’s Wikidata item, name, playing position, tenure start and end dates, number of games played, goals scored, and an image. It also fetches the player’s English Wikipedia article and ranks them by the number of Wikipedia language links, highlighting more notable players.

context: Share of women for each Nobel prize
target: This SPARQL query analyzes Nobel Prize awards by gender. It retrieves each award type and counts how many male and female recipients there are, using gender identifiers. It then calculates the total recipients and the percentage of female winners per award. Finally, it orders the results to highlight awards with the highest share of female laureates, providing insight into gender distribution across Nobel categories.

context: Nobel Prize statistics on number of recipients for award wrt. gender (interactive plot)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves statistics on Nobel Prize recipients by gender. It counts how many male and female recipients each Nobel Prize award has, grouping results by award type. The query fetches award labels in multiple languages and orders the data by the number of male recipients, then female recipients. The output supports an interactive scatter chart showing gender distribution across awards.

context: Share of women among Nobel prize winners by decade
target: This SPARQL query calculates the share of women Nobel Prize winners by decade. It groups Nobel laureates by the decade they received the award, counts how many winners are male or female, and computes the percentage of female winners per decade. The query uses gender identifiers and award dates to aggregate and order results from recent to older decades.

context: Notable books on linked data, semantic technologies, and semantic knowledge graphs
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of notable books about linked data, semantic technologies, and semantic knowledge graphs. For each book (identified by specific Wikidata IDs), it fetches the title, publication date, and concatenates the authors' names into a single string. It handles author names from multiple properties and filters for English or language-neutral labels to ensure consistent author information.

context: Benelux railway stations connected from
target: This SPARQL query finds railway stations connected to Brussels-South station (Q800587) within the Benelux countries (Belgium, Luxembourg, Netherlands). It uses a breadth-first search to explore linked stations via railway connections (property P197), excluding closed stations. For each station, it retrieves coordinates, connection lines, track info, and images, outputting data suitable for mapping routes.

context: Date of opening and closing of railway stations in Denmark
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Danish railway stations (instances of or subclasses of "railway station") along with their labels, geographic coordinates, and operational dates. It fetches each station’s official opening or inception date as the start, and closure or end time as the end date, filtering to include only stations with at least one of these dates defined. Labels are returned in Danish or English.

context: Map or Talaiotic archeological culture sites located in the Menorca island in Spain
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Talaiotic archaeological sites located on Menorca island (Wikidata entity Q52636). It selects items classified as Talaiotic sites (Q530894) that are situated within Menorca or its subdivisions. For each site, it fetches labels, geographic coordinates, images, and administrative location details, enabling a map-based visualization of these cultural heritage locations.

context: Location of all the meteorological stations in Navarre
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all meteorological stations located in Navarre (Q4018). For each station, it fetches its name (in Basque or Spanish), geographic coordinates, and elevation above sea level. The query uses hierarchical location properties to ensure stations within Navarre are included, providing data ideal for mapping weather stations in the region.

context: Photos of participants in the Pandora Papers
target: This SPARQL query retrieves participants involved in the Pandora Papers (entity Q108782773) along with their country of citizenship and a sample photo. For each person linked to the Pandora Papers, it fetches their name, description, country label, and one image. Results are grouped by person and country, then ordered alphabetically by country, ideal for displaying a photo grid of participants by nationality.

context: French departments with their shape
target: This SPARQL query retrieves French departments along with their geographic shapes from Wikidata. It selects entities classified as French departments (wd:Q6465) and fetches their associated shape data (wdt:P3896). The results include the department's name, its shape, and use the name as a map layer label, enabling visualization of French departments with their boundaries on a map.

context: Longest rivers located in France and which did not gave their name to a department
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 10 longest rivers in France that have not lent their name to any French department. It selects each river’s length and optionally its continent. The results include labels in French and are ordered by river length in descending order, highlighting major French rivers without departmental namesakes.

query:
# some repetitive taxon names
SELECT ?taxon ?taxonName WHERE {
  ?taxon wdt:P225 ?taxonName.
  # e.g. gorilla gorilla or gorilla gorilla gorilla
  FILTER(REGEX(?taxonName, "^([^ ]*) \\1( \\1)?$", "i"))
}
LIMIT 500
context: Repetitive taxon names
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 500 taxa whose scientific names contain repeated words, like "Gorilla gorilla" or "Gorilla gorilla gorilla." It selects taxa (`?taxon`) and their names (`?taxonName`) from Wikidata, filtering names that match a pattern where the first word repeats once or twice consecutively, ignoring case. This helps identify taxa with repetitive naming conventions.

query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?labelFr ?nomCOG ?pop ?image ?coord WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q484170. #Commune française
  FILTER NOT EXISTS { ?item wdt:P576 ?end_date . } # Qui n'a pas de date de fin (on veut les communes actuelles)
  
  ?item rdfs:label ?labelFr . FILTER(LANG(?labelFr) = "fr") # Nom en français

  ?item wdt:P1448 ?nomCOG . # Nom officiel dans le code officiel géographique  

  BIND(STRLEN(STR(?labelFr)) AS ?nameLength) # Nombre de caractères
  FILTER (?nameLength > 30) # Fitre pour ne garder que les valeurs supérieures à 30

  OPTIONAL { ?item wdt:P1082 ?pop . } # Dernières données de population
  OPTIONAL { ?item wdt:P625 ?coord . } # Coordonnées
  OPTIONAL { ?item wdt:P18 ?image . } # Et juste là, un petit geranium.
} ORDER BY DESC(?nameLength)
context: Map of French communes that are >30 characters long
target: This SPARQL query retrieves current French communes (municipalities) whose French names exceed 30 characters. For each, it fetches the official geographic name, French label, population, coordinates, and an image if available. It excludes communes that have an end date (no longer existing) and orders results by descending name length, highlighting unusually long commune names.

context: Lexemes in Swedish that are missing in Svenska Akademiens Ordbok (Q1935308)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Swedish lexemes (words or lemmas) that are not yet included in the Svenska Akademiens Ordbok (SAOB). It selects lexemes where the language is Swedish (Q9027) and filters for those marked as missing from SAOB (property P9660 with value Q1935308), helping identify vocabulary gaps in this authoritative Swedish dictionary.

context: Attendance at the Bargoin, Roger-Quilliot and Henri-Lecoq museums per year
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the average annual visitor numbers for three specific museums: Bargoin, Roger-Quilliot, and Henri-Lecoq. It extracts visitor counts linked to dates, groups them by museum and year, and calculates the average visitors per year. The query also fetches the museum names for easier interpretation, ideal for visualizing attendance trends over time.

context: Present and past members of Czech Chamber of Deputies who are relatives
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of present or past members of the Czech Chamber of Deputies (?item1 and ?item2) who are related to each other. It checks if both individuals held the position (P39) of Czech Chamber of Deputies member (Q19803234) and if they share a family relationship like parent, child, spouse, or sibling (properties P1038, P3373, P22, P25, P40, P26). Labels are returned in Czech or English.

context: Map of mosques
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of mosques from Wikidata, including their names and geographic coordinates. It selects items classified as mosques (wd:Q32815 or its subclasses) that have location data (P625). The results include the mosque’s entity, its label in the user’s language or English, and coordinates, ideal for plotting on a map.

context: Documents from the Boyer collection by decades
target: This SPARQL query counts documents from the Boyer collection by decade. It selects items held in the Boyer collection (wd:Q108427678) with their dates (wdt:P577), extracts the year from each date, groups these years into decades by dividing by 10 and flooring the result, then counts how many documents fall into each decade. The results are ideal for a bar chart visualization.

context: Pronouns of people in different languages
target: This SPARQL query retrieves and counts the different pronouns associated with people (instances of human, Q5) in Wikidata. It selects each pronoun’s identifier and its label (the actual pronoun text), then groups the results by pronoun and orders them by frequency in descending order. The output helps visualize the distribution of pronouns used for people across languages.

context: Twitter accounts of libraries in Switzerland
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Swiss libraries (instances of libraries located in Switzerland) from Wikidata. For each library, it fetches its Wikidata ID and label, constructs a Twitter URL from its Twitter username, and optionally includes its logo and geographic coordinates. The results help map Swiss libraries with their social media presence and location data.

query:
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?image ?cl
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P7963 ?cl . 
  
  ?item wdt:P18 ?image .
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
context: Images of cell types in Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves cell types from Wikidata that have associated images. For each cell type (?item), it fetches its label (?itemLabel), an image (?image), and a classification code (?cl) linked via property P7963. The query also uses a label service to display names in your language or English by default, enabling a visual gallery of cell types with their images and classifications.

context: Map of the place of death of people born in Puy-de-Dôme
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people born in Puy-de-Dôme (Q12694) or its subdivisions and their places of death. For each person, it gets their name, the death location's name, and geographic coordinates. The results can be visualized on a map, showing where individuals born in Puy-de-Dôme died, using labels in the user's language or English.

context: Graph of NFDI consortia with their fields of work
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all NFDI consortia (entities instance of Q98270496) along with their fields of work. For each consortium (?p), it fetches the field (?w) and their English labels. It also optionally gets a field picture if available. The results include a fixed color code "EC0000" and are ordered alphabetically by the field's label, useful for visualizing the consortia-to-field graph.

context: Places where people in South-America work who published on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query finds authors linked to works about "South America" (wd:Q2013) and retrieves their organizations located in specific South American countries. For each author, it shows their name, affiliated organization, an example work, and the organization's location on a map. It also includes the author's ORCID if available, or a quick ORCID search link otherwise.

context: Rail link between Narvik and Singapore
target: This SPARQL query finds all stations on the shortest path between Narvik (wd:Q3097173) and Singapore (wd:Q6132101) using a breadth-first search (BFS) graph algorithm. It retrieves each station’s coordinates and constructs geographic linestrings representing rail links between consecutive points. The results include station names and geospatial data for mapping the rail connection.

context: Map of French bridges and tunnels carrying an high-speed railway line
target: This SPARQL query retrieves French bridges and tunnels (ouvrages) that carry a high-speed railway line (ligne). For each structure, it fetches its name, associated railway line, geographic coordinates, and an optional image. The query ensures results are labeled in French and returns distinct entries to map these infrastructures accurately.

query:
# See https://m.wikidata.org/wiki/User:PAC2/Gender_neutral_labels
#title: Items with male form as a generic form in French
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel ?femaleform ?maleform ?lang WHERE {
  wd:Q12737077 (^(wdt:P279*)/^wdt:P31) ?item.
  ?item wdt:P2521 ?femaleform;
    wdt:P3321 ?maleform;
    rdfs:label ?itemLabel.
  BIND(LANG(?itemLabel) AS ?lang)
  FILTER((LANG(?itemLabel)) = "fr")
  FILTER((LANG(?femaleform)) = ?lang)
  FILTER((LANG(?maleform)) = ?lang)
  FILTER(?itemLabel = ?maleform)
  FILTER(?itemLabel != ?femaleform)
}
ORDER BY ?item
LIMIT 100
context: List of Wikidata item's labels which are same as male form and different from female form in French (ie using the generic as male form)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 Wikidata items related to a specific category (Q12737077) where the French label of the item matches the male form but differs from the female form. It selects items whose French generic term uses the male form as the default label, highlighting gender-neutral labels where the male term serves as the generic reference instead of the female one.

query:
# See https://m.wikidata.org/wiki/User:PAC2/Gender_neutral_labels
#title: Items with male form as a generic form in English 
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?femaleform ?maleform ?lang WHERE {
  wd:Q12737077 ^wdt:P279*/^wdt:P31 ?item. 
 ?item wdt:P2521 ?femaleform;
    wdt:P3321 ?maleform;
    rdfs:label ?itemLabel.
  BIND(LANG(?itemLabel) AS ?lang) 
  FILTER((LANG(?itemLabel)) = "en")
  FILTER((LANG(?femaleform)) = ?lang)
  FILTER((LANG(?maleform)) = ?lang)
  FILTER(?itemLabel = ?maleform) 
  FILTER(?itemLabel != ?femaleform) 
}
LIMIT 100
context: List of Wikidata item's labels which are same as male form and different from female form in English (ie using the generic as male form)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 Wikidata items where the English label matches the male form of a term but differs from the female form. It focuses on items related to gender-neutral labels, identifying cases where the male form is used as the generic English label, while the female form is distinct. The query ensures all labels are in English.

context: consorts of Selim III
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about the consorts (spouses) of Selim III (wd:Q199633). It lists each consort along with their order (if specified), date of death, place of death, and place of burial. The query also fetches human-readable labels and descriptions for these places and consorts, using Wikidata’s label service to provide results in the user’s language or English.

context: Coordinates of the birthplaces of people with family name Autrique
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people whose family name is "Autrique" (wd:Q11134722) from Wikidata. For each person (?item), it finds their place of birth (?place) and fetches the geographic coordinates (?coord) of that birthplace. The query also gets the person's label (?itemLabel) in French. The results can be visualized on a map showing birth locations of individuals named Autrique.

context: Coordinates of battles
target: This SPARQL query retrieves battles and their details from Wikidata. It selects items classified as battles (Q645883) or their subclasses, along with optional dates (?point_in_time) and geographic coordinates (?coords). The query also fetches labels in the user's language or English. The default map view visualizes these battles by location.

context: Geographical distribution of votive boats historic monuments in France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct historic monuments in France classified as votive boats. It selects items that are both monuments and votive boats, linked to ongoing communes (without an end date), and located at specific places with geographic coordinates. For each item, it fetches labels, an identifier, optional images, and coordinates—ideal for mapping their distribution.

context: Relationship among accepted NFDI consortia
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about entities classified as accepted NFDI consortia (instances of Q98270496). For each consortium (?p), it fetches its main discipline (?w) and optionally a secondary discipline (?w2). It also obtains labels in German or English and assigns a fixed color code ("EC0000"). The results are sorted by the main discipline's label, helping visualize relationships among these consortia.

context: Number of virtual twins (pair with the same dates of birth and death) in Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query counts the cumulative number of "virtual twins" in Wikidata over time. Virtual twins are pairs of items linked by a specific property indicating they share identical birth and death dates. The query aggregates these pairs by milestone timestamps, showing how many such twins existed up to each date, enabling visualization of their growth as an area chart.

context: People recently buried in a cemetery nearby without an image of the grave (P1442) on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query finds people who have been buried since 2015 in a nearby cemetery (an instance of a cemetery) but whose graves lack an image on Wikidata (property P1442). It retrieves details like the person's name, death date, cemetery location, related Wikimedia Commons categories, Find a Grave links, and available photos of the person or cemetery, helping identify graves needing images.

context: List of lexemes in French associated with occupation items
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a distinct list of French lexemes (words) related to occupation items, along with their grammatical gender. It selects lexical entries in French, linking each lexeme to its meaning (sense) and the occupation item it describes. The query filters labels and gender information to French, ensuring the results show occupation-related terms with their French labels and gender classifications, ordered by item, lemma, and gender.

context: Towns with less than 1000 people that have a cathedral
target: This SPARQL query retrieves towns with cathedrals that have fewer than 1000 inhabitants. It selects each cathedral (?item) and its location (?place), along with population, country, coordinates, and images if available. Results include labels in the user's language and are ordered by population, helping visualize small towns hosting cathedrals on a map.

context: Musical works based on literary works
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct songs (?song) that are based on literary works (?book). It filters for books classified under a specific literary category (Q7725634) and songs classified as musical works (Q2188189). For each song, it fetches its label (?songLabel) and a code (?code), then orders the results by the length of the code (ignoring spaces) in descending order. This helps identify musical adaptations of literature, prioritizing those with longer codes.

context: Main surnames of people born in the Puy-de-Dôme, France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 30 most common surnames of people born in Puy-de-Dôme, France (wd:Q12694). It counts individuals (?q) whose place of birth (P19) is within Puy-de-Dôme or its subdivisions (P131*). The results list each surname (?nom) with its label and the count (?ct), ideal for visualizing surname distribution in the region.

context: List of properties which have instances or subclass of humans as possible value with male and female form in French
target: This SPARQL query retrieves properties that can have humans (or their subclasses) as values, specifically focusing on those with French labels. It lists each property along with its French label, the type of relation it represents (also labeled in French), and optionally includes the male and female forms of the property name in French. This helps identify gendered property names related to humans.

query:
select distinct ?person1 ?person2 ?Label ?birthday ?occupation where
{
  ?person1 wdt:P569 ?birthday . ?person2 wdt:P569 ?birthday . 
  filter (?birthday >= "1706-01-01"^^xsd:dateTime) .   filter (?birthday < "1707-01-01"^^xsd:dateTime) .
  ?person1 rdfs:label ?Label . filter(lang(?Label) = "en") .
  ?person2 rdfs:label ?Label . 
  ?person1 wdt:P106 ?occ . ?person2 wdt:P106 ?occ . 
  ?occ rdfs:label ?occupation . filter(lang(?occupation) = "en") .
  filter (str(?person1) > str(?person2))
}
context: Different people with same label / birthday / occupation in a specified year
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of distinct people born in 1706 who share the same English name (label) and occupation. It retrieves each person’s identifier, their shared name, birthdate, and occupation. By comparing string values of their URIs, it ensures each pair is unique and avoids duplicates, highlighting cases of name and job overlap in that year.

context: Narrative locations of the book Itinerary from Paris to Mont-d'Or
target: This SPARQL query retrieves locations mentioned in the narrative "Itinerary from Paris to Mont-d'Or" (wd:Q108366183). For each place (?lieu), it gets its name (?lieuLabel), the date or layer associated with that mention (?layer), and geographic coordinates (?coord). The results help map the story’s journey by linking places to specific times and locations.

context: Maps of tombs of unknown soldiers
target: This SPARQL query retrieves items classified as "tombs of unknown soldiers" (`wd:Q1541043`) along with their associated countries. It filters out any countries that have a dissolution date (`wdt:P576`), ensuring only current countries are included. For each tomb, it optionally fetches geographic coordinates (`wdt:P625`) and images (`wdt:P18`). Labels for items, countries, and other data are returned in the user's language or English. The default view is set to display results on a map.

context: Most common first names (> 5) among people with a Wikidata item and born in Auvergne
target: This SPARQL query finds the most common first names of people born in the Auvergne region. It counts individuals (?q) whose birthplace is within Auvergne (wd:Q1152) or its subdivisions, grouping results by first name (?prenomLabel). Only names with more than five occurrences are shown. The query returns these popular first names with their counts, ideal for a bubble chart visualization.

context: Student-Teacher relationship based on entries in 'Das Geistige Berlin' (1897)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves student-teacher relationships documented in the 1897 publication *Das Geistige Berlin*. It finds individuals (?student) linked to their teachers (?teacher) via the property P1066, but only when this information is sourced from the specific reference Q109118295, representing *Das Geistige Berlin*. The query also fetches readable labels for both parties and assigns a fixed edge label ("student of") and color code ("cbcbcb") for visualization purposes.

query:
SELECT ?value ?lemma {
  ?number wdt:P31 wd:Q21199 ; wdt:P1181 ?value .
  FILTER (?value >= 0 && ?value <= 20) .
  ?lexeme dct:language wd:Q150 ; wikibase:lemma ?lemma ; ontolex:sense ?sense .
  ?sense wdt:P5137 ?number .
}
ORDER BY ?lemma
context: Numbers from 0 to 20 sorted alphabetically thanks to lexicographical data
target: This SPARQL query retrieves numbers from 0 to 20 along with their corresponding lemmas (words) in German. It selects entities classified as numbers (wd:Q21199) with values between 0 and 20, then links each number to its lexeme (word form) in German (language code Q150). Finally, it orders the results alphabetically by the lemma, providing a sorted list of number words.

context: Given names of French fictional characters, as chosen by French / non-French authors
target: This SPARQL query counts French fictional characters grouped by their given names and whether their authors speak French. It selects characters classified as fictional humans linked to the French language, retrieves their given names, and identifies if their authors are French speakers. The results show how often each name appears, split by author language, enabling analysis of naming patterns by French vs. non-French authors.

context: Map of members of the International Society of Biocuration (historical and current; affiliation and education institutions)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves members (both current and historical) of the International Society of Biocuration, along with their affiliated or educational organizations. It then fetches the geographic coordinates of these organizations to plot them on a map. Labels for people and organizations are included for easy identification in the selected language.

context: UK MPs and their reason for *finally* leaving office
target: This SPARQL query analyzes UK Members of Parliament (MPs) to identify the reasons they *finally* left office, grouped by decade from 1870 to 2019. It counts distinct MPs per exit cause each decade, calculates the percentage of each cause relative to all departures that decade, and retrieves human-readable cause labels. The result highlights trends in MPs' exit reasons over time.

context: Number of new UK MPs at each general election since 1870 (new = never served before)
target: This SPARQL query counts the number of UK Members of Parliament (MPs) elected for the first time at each general election since 1870. It identifies each MP’s earliest term start date, filters for those starting in or after 1870, and groups them by election date. The result shows how many new MPs entered Parliament at each election, useful for analyzing turnover over time.

context: Crewe Alexandra players from Crewe
target: This SPARQL query retrieves players of the football club Crewe Alexandra who were born in Crewe. It selects each player's Wikidata item, label (name), description, and image. The query filters for individuals born in Crewe (P19: place of birth), with the occupation "football player" (P106), and who have played for Crewe Alexandra (P54: member of sports team). The results include images and labels in the user's language.

context: Chronological timeline of people buried in Cimetière des Carmes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of people buried in the Cimetière des Carmes cemetery. It selects each person’s Wikidata entity, their labels (names), birth dates (?dateN), and death dates (?dateM). The query filters individuals linked to the cemetery (wd:Q2972588) and fetches labels in the user's language or English, enabling a chronological view of those interred there.

context: Stops in the travel routes of Wilhelm Müller on his way from Leipzig to Bad Schandau in 1820/21
target: This SPARQL query retrieves geographic data about specific places linked to a travel report (Q109590352) by Wilhelm Müller from 1820/21. It extracts pairs of locations (?ort1 and ?ort2) mentioned as keywords in the report, fetches their German labels and precise coordinates, and constructs WKT LINESTRING geometries representing routes between these points. This enables mapping Müller’s travel stops visually.

query: SELECT (COUNT(*) as ?count) { ?item wikibase:statements 0 }
context: Number of items without any statements
target: This SPARQL query counts how many items in a Wikibase instance have zero statements. It searches for all items where the property `wikibase:statements` equals 0, meaning these items lack any associated data or claims. The result is a single number representing the total count of such empty or unpopulated items.

query:
#title:items without claims count by wiki in sitelinks
SELECT ?partof (COUNT(*) as ?count)
{
  ?item wikibase:statements 0 . 
  [] schema:about ?item ; schema:isPartOf ?partof . 
}
GROUP BY ?partof
context: Number of items without any statements by sitelinks
target: This SPARQL query counts how many Wikidata items have no statements (i.e., no claims) and groups these counts by the wiki site where they appear as sitelinks. It finds items with zero statements, identifies which Wikimedia project (like Wikipedia in different languages) links to them, and tallies the number of such "empty" items per site, helping assess data completeness across wikis.

query:
#title: Taxa nomeados em homenagem a uma mulher (por lugar de nascimento)
#defaultView:Map
SELECT ?taxon ?taxonLabel ?pessoa ?pessoaLabel ?lugar ?lugarLabel ?coordenadas
WHERE

  ?lugar wdt:P625 ?coordenadas .

context: Taxa named after women (by place of birth)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves taxa (biological classifications) named after women, along with the women's birthplaces and geographic coordinates. It selects taxa instances linked to a female person, identifies that person's birthplace, and fetches the location's coordinates. Labels are returned in Portuguese or English, enabling visualization on a map by birthplace.

query:
#title: Liste des articles sur Blaise Pascal dans toutes les Wikipédia, classés par taille décroissante de l’article
SELECT ?sitelink ?site ?title ?taille
WHERE
{
  ?sitelink schema:about wd:Q1290.
  ?sitelink schema:isPartOf ?site.
  ?sitelink schema:isPartOf/wikibase:wikiGroup "wikipedia" .
  ?sitelink schema:name ?title.
  BIND (STRBEFORE(STRAFTER(STR(?site), "https://"), "/") AS ?endpoint)
  BIND (STR(?title) AS ?title_nolang)
  SERVICE wikibase:mwapi
  {
    bd:serviceParam wikibase:endpoint ?endpoint.
    bd:serviceParam wikibase:api "Generator".
    bd:serviceParam mwapi:generator "revisions".
    bd:serviceParam mwapi:titles ?title_nolang.
    bd:serviceParam mwapi:prop "revisions".
    bd:serviceParam mwapi:rvprop "size".
    ?size wikibase:apiOutput "revisions/rev[last()]/@size".
  }
  BIND ( xsd:integer(?size) AS ?taille )
}
ORDER BY DESC(?taille)
context: List of articles on Blaise Pascal in all Wikipedias, sorted by decreasing article size
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all Wikipedia articles about Blaise Pascal across different language editions. For each article, it fetches the site link, site identifier, article title, and the latest revision size (in bytes). It uses the MediaWiki API to get the current article size, then sorts the results by descending size, effectively listing Pascal articles from largest to smallest.

context: Texts on French Wikisource by people born in Puy-de-Dôme
target: This SPARQL query retrieves French Wikisource texts authored by individuals born in the Puy-de-Dôme region. It finds books linked to their creators, filters those whose birthplace is within Puy-de-Dôme or its subdivisions, then identifies Wikisource pages about these books. The results list the author’s name, the book title, and the corresponding Wikisource page, ordered by author.

context: List of countries by the highest elevation point
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of sovereign countries along with their highest geographical points and the elevation of those points. It selects each country (?item) and its label, the highest point (?highest) with its label, and the elevation in meters. The results are ordered from the highest to the lowest elevation, providing a ranked list of countries by their tallest natural features.

context: Number of distinct (UK parliament) seats returning someone who chose to sit elsewhere each year, 1830-1910
target: This SPARQL query counts, for each year from 1830 to 1910, the number of distinct UK parliamentary seats that elected MPs who ultimately chose to sit elsewhere. It identifies parliamentary terms linked to elections and checks for MPs who held a seat but have a qualifier indicating they opted to represent a different constituency. The results are grouped by year and formatted as year-month for visualization.

context: List of services that support the OpenRefine Reconciliation service
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of services that support the OpenRefine Reconciliation API (identified by the property qualifier `pq:P2700` with value `wd:Q64490175`). For each service, it fetches the service name, endpoint URL, optional documentation links, and source references. Deprecated statements are excluded, and labels are returned in the user's language or English. Results are sorted by endpoint URL in descending order.

context: Things depicted in art works in the Khalili Collections
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of subjects depicted in artworks from the Khalili Collections (Q63160499). For each subject, it fetches a link to their Wikidata page, a combined label and description, and one sample image from the related artworks. Results are grouped by subject and sorted alphabetically, providing a clear overview of what is portrayed in these art pieces.

context: Population density of administrative subdivisions exceeding 100,000 km² and 100 inhabitants / km²
target: This SPARQL query retrieves large administrative subdivisions (over 100,000 km²) with population data from Wikidata. It selects entities classified under a specific administrative type (Q10864048), ensures they belong to recognized countries, and excludes deprecated or dissolved entries. The query calculates area in square kilometers, filters for size, fetches population, then computes population density, returning labels, country, coordinates, and sorting results by area size.

context: List of government agencies in Scotland
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a comprehensive list of Scottish government agencies, covering various types like executive agencies, non-departmental public bodies, commissioners, public corporations, tribunals, local authorities, health boards, and courts. It filters entities linked to Scotland (wd:Q22), excludes abolished or replaced ones, and fetches their English labels and types, grouping results to avoid duplicates.

query:
#defaultView:BarChart
SELECT ?weekday (count(distinct(?item)) as ?count) WHERE {
  wd:Q362 wdt:P580 ?od ; wdt:P582 ?do. 
  ?item wdt:P20 wd:Q160139 .
  ?item p:P570 [ps:P570 ?date ; psv:P570/wikibase:timePrecision ?precision ] filter(?precision = 11 && day(?date) != 1 && ?date > ?od && ?date < ?do ). 
  BIND( DAY( ?date ) AS ?q ) .
  BIND( MONTH( ?date ) + IF( MONTH( ?date ) < 3, 12, 0 ) AS ?m ) .
  BIND( YEAR( ?date ) - IF( MONTH( ?date ) < 3, 1, 0 ) AS ?_year ) .
  BIND( ?_year - FLOOR( ?_year / 100 ) * 100 AS ?K ) . # modulo
  BIND( FLOOR( YEAR( ?date ) / 100 ) AS ?J ) .
  BIND( ?q + FLOOR( 13 * ( ?m + 1 ) / 5 ) + ?K + FLOOR( ?K / 4 ) + FLOOR( ?J / 4 ) - 2 * ?J AS ?_h ) .
  BIND(( ?_h - FLOOR( ?_h / 7 ) * 7) as ?day) . 
  BIND(if(?day=0,"06 (Saturday)",if(?day=1,"07 (Sunday)",if(?day=2,"01 (Monday)",if(?day=3,"02 (Tuesday)",if(?day=4,"03 (Wednesday)",if(?day=5,"04 (Thursday)",if(?day=6,"05 (Friday)",""))))))) as ?weekday) . 
} group by ?weekday order by asc(?weekday)
context: Which day of the week people died on in the Mauthausen concentration camp
target: This SPARQL query analyzes death dates of individuals who died in the Mauthausen concentration camp (wd:Q160139) during the camp’s operation period (from start date P580 to end date P582 of wd:Q362). It calculates the weekday of each death using Zeller’s congruence, excluding deaths recorded only by month or on the first day. The result counts distinct deaths per weekday, showing which days had more fatalities, visualized as a bar chart.

query:
#title:word cloud articles without statements MyLangWikipedia (switch to "Table" view to list, at left border of screen)
#defaultView:BubbleChart
SELECT
  ?word
  (COUNT(*) as ?count) 
  (URI(CONCAT("https://www.wikidata.org/w/index.php?search=inlabel%3A",?word,"%40[AUTO_LANGUAGE]+-haswbstatement%3A%2A&profile=advanced&fulltext=1&ns=1")) as ?search)
WITH
{
  SELECT ?item (CONCAT(?n, " 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 ") as ?string) 
  {
    ?item wikibase:statements 0 .
    [] schema:about ?item ; schema:name ?n ; schema:isPartOf <https://[AUTO_LANGUAGE].wikipedia.org/>
  }
  LIMIT 20000
} as %aa
WITH
{
  SELECT (str(?nv-1) as ?ord) { [] wdt:P5176 ?i ; wdt:P1181 ?nv . FILTER( ?nv < 8) } 
} as %i  
WHERE
{
  INCLUDE %i
  INCLUDE %aa
  BIND(  CONCAT("^([^ ]+ ){",?ord,"}([^ ]+) .+$") as ?re)         
  BIND(  REPLACE(?string, ?re, "$2") as ?word)
  # FILTER( ?word != "1" && )
  FILTER( strlen(?word) > 4)           
} 
GROUP BY ?word
ORDER BY DESC(?count) 
LIMIT 100
context: Wordcloud articles without statements of MyLang Wikipedia
target: This SPARQL query identifies the most frequent words in article titles from a specific language Wikipedia (MyLang) that have no linked Wikidata statements. It extracts up to 20,000 such articles, parses their titles word-by-word, filters out short words, and counts occurrences. The result is a word cloud highlighting common words in these "statement-less" articles, with links to search for them on Wikidata.

context: Artworks picturing snow
target: This SPARQL query retrieves artworks that depict snow. It selects items (?q) linked to subjects (?depeint) associated with snow (wd:Q7561) via any property (?prop), and that have an image (?img). The query returns each artwork’s label and one sample image, grouping results by artwork. It’s ideal for displaying a gallery of snow-themed artworks.

query:
SELECT (?year_d as ?year) (COUNT(?futbolari)as ?count) WHERE {
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
  ?futbolari wdt:P106 wd:Q937857.
  ?futbolari wdt:P570 ?heriotza_data.
  ?futbolari wdt:P569 ?jaiotza_data.
  BIND (year(?heriotza_data) as ?year_d).
  BIND (year(?jaiotza_data) as ?year_j).
  BIND (?year_d - ?year_j as ?age).
  FILTER (?age < 40)
}
GROUP by ?year_d
context: Graph of football players who died per year
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of football players who died each year before turning 40. It selects individuals with the occupation "football player," extracts their birth and death years, calculates their age at death, and filters to include only those who died younger than 40. Finally, it groups the results by death year, counting players per year.

context: Things depicted in art works of the Khalili Collections
target: This SPARQL query retrieves entities depicted in artworks from the Khalili Collections (Q63160499). For each depicted subject, it fetches a link to its Wikidata page, a combined label and description, and one sample image from the artworks showing it. context: People represented on the painting "Le Sacre de Napoléon" from 1804 by Jacques-Louis David
target: This SPARQL query retrieves images and information about people depicted in the painting "Le Sacre de Napoléon" (1804) by Jacques-Louis David. query:
SELECT * WHERE {
    ?place wdt:P31 wd:Q42744322 ;               # German municipalities
           wdt:P1448 ?name .                    # their official names
    BIND(lcase(?name) as ?lemma)                # use the names in lower case as lemma
    ?lexeme wikibase:lemma ?lemma ;             # lexemes with that lemma
            wikibase:lexicalCategory wd:Q24905; # verbs
            dct:language wd:Q188                # in German
}
context: German cities whose names are also verbs (using Lexemes)
target: This SPARQL query finds German municipalities whose official names are also German verbs. It selects places classified as German municipalities (wd:Q42744322) and retrieves their official names (wdt:P1448). These names are converted to lowercase and matched against lexemes labeled with the same lemma, specifically verbs (wd:Q24905) in the German language (wd:Q188).

query:
# (Thanks, James Heald, for the original query!)
#defaultView:Map
SELECT ?station ?line (CEIL(?depth/10)*10 as ?layer) ?coord {
  SERVICE gas:service {
       gas:program gas:gasClass "com.bigdata.rdf.graph.analytics.BFS" ; gas:in wd:Q2660080 ; gas:out ?station ; gas:out1 ?depth ; gas:out2 ?pred .
       gas:program gas:linkType wdt:P197 . }
  FILTER(?station != wd:Q2660080)
                      ?pred wdt:P625 ?cds.
                      BIND(IF(xsd:double(?depth/10) = xsd:integer(?depth/10),?cds,"") as ?coords)
  ?pred p:P625/psv:P625/wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat1 ; p:P625/psv:P625/wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon1 .
  ?station p:P625/psv:P625/wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat2 ; p:P625/psv:P625/wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon2 .
  values ?country { wd:Q211 wd:Q37 wd:Q191 wd:Q159 wd:Q184 } ?station wdt:P17 ?country . 
  # only Baltics or Russia or Belarus
  BIND(CONCAT('LINESTRING(', STR(?lon1), ' ', STR(?lat1), ',', STR(?lon2), ' ', STR(?lat2), ')') AS ?str) . BIND(STRDT(?str, geo:wktLiteral) AS ?line) 
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "bn,en". }
  ?station wdt:P625 ?coord.
}
context: Railway stations in the Baltics
target: This SPARQL query finds railway stations connected to a specific starting station (wd:Q2660080) in the Baltics and nearby countries (Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Russia, Belarus). It uses a breadth-first search to explore linked stations, calculates their distance layers by depth, and retrieves geographic coordinates. The query outputs each station, a line representing the connection, a depth-based layer, and coordinates for mapping.

query:
#title:5 people died on their 50th birthday
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?dob ?dod WHERE {
  ?item (p:P569/psv:P569) _:b44.
  _:b44 wikibase:timePrecision 11;
    wikibase:timeValue ?dob.
  ?item (p:P570/psv:P570) _:b45.
  _:b45 wikibase:timePrecision 11;
    wikibase:timeValue ?dod.
  #FILTER(?precisionDob = 11 )
  #FILTER(?precisionDod = 11 )
  FILTER((DAY(?dob)) = (DAY(?dod)))
  FILTER((MONTH(?dob)) = (MONTH(?dod)))
  FILTER( ((YEAR(?dod)) - (YEAR(?dob))) = 50)
  ?item rdfs:label ?itemLabel. FILTER(LANG(?itemLabel)="de")
}
LIMIT 5

query:
SELECT 
(GROUP_CONCAT(?occupationLabel; SEPARATOR= ", ") as ?occupations)
?item ?linkcount ?itemLabel
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P27 wd:Q155 . 
  ?item wikibase:sitelinks ?linkcount .
  
  OPTIONAL{
    ?item wdt:P106 ?occupation .
    ?occupation rdfs:label ?occupationLabel . 
    FILTER(LANG(?occupationLabel)="pt") .
    } .
  
  ?item rdfs:label ?itemLabel .

query:
#title: Presidentes do Brasil com mais premiações
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?image 
("Exemplo de premiação:" as ?s)
?award_label ?sample_award ?sample_awardLabel
WHERE
{
  
 {
  SELECT ?item ?image
  (COUNT(DISTINCT ?award) as ?award_count)
  (CONCAT("Número de premiações: ", STR( ?award_count )) AS ?award_label )
  (SAMPLE(?award) as ?sample_award)
  WHERE 
  {
    ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q5 .
    ?item wdt:P39 wd:Q5176750 .
    ?item wdt:P166 ?award .
    ?item wdt:P18 ?image .
  }
   GROUP BY  ?item ?itemLabel ?image ?award_label

 }
   SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "pt-br","pt". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
  
ORDER BY DESC(?award_count)
context: Presidents of Brazil with the most awards

Results are ordered by the number of awards in descending order, displaying labels in Portuguese when available.

query:
#title:World map of recent censuses known at Wikidata for each decade (select decade on the right side)
#defaultView:Map{"hide":["?loc","?locLabel","?dg","?geoshape","?decade"], "layer": "?decade"}
#from https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property_talk:P8701 query, by Jura1, 2022-01-10
SELECT 
  ?loc ?locLabel ?geoshape ?decade 
  ?dg
  (URI(concat(str(?dg),"#P8701")) as ?available_census) 
  (CONCAT(?locLabel, ": ", GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT ?year; separator=", ")) as ?available_censusLabel) 
WHERE
{
  ?dg wdt:P8701 / wdt:P585 ?d . 
  FILTER( year(?d) > 1959) 
  BIND( str(YEAR(?d)) as ?year)
  BIND( CONCAT(str(FLOOR(YEAR(?d)/10)*10),"s") as ?decade) 
  ?dg wdt:P276 ?loc .
  OPTIONAL { ?loc wdt:P3896 ?geoshape }
  BIND(URI(concat(str(?dg),"#P8701")) as ?available_census) 
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
}  
GROUP BY ?loc ?locLabel ?geoshape ?decade ?dg
ORDER BY DESC(?decade)
context: World map of recent censuses known at Wikidata for each decade
target: This SPARQL query retrieves recent census data from Wikidata, focusing on censuses conducted after 1959. For each census entity, it identifies the location, decade (grouped by 10-year periods), and geographic shape if available. The results group censuses by location and decade, enabling a world map visualization that highlights where and when censuses occurred, with labels listing census years per place.

query:
select  (concat(str(?day), "/", str(?month)) as ?date)  (count(distinct ?ps) as ?count) 
where {
  ?MP p:P39 ?ps . ?ps ps:P39 ?term . ?term wdt:P279 wd:Q16707842 .
  ?ps pq:P2715 ?election .
  ?ps pq:P580 ?elected .
  ?election wdt:P31* wd:Q7864918 . 
  bind(day(?elected) as ?day) . bind(month(?elected) as ?month) .
  filter(year(?elected) >= 1880) . 
} group by ?day ?month order by desc(?count)

target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of rabbis (or related religious figures) along with their birth details from Wikidata. The birthplace is geolocated for mapping, and results are ordered by birth date ascending, enabling visualization of rabbis’ birthplaces over time.

query:
# Parlamentari e ministri 50-80enni
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel (COUNT(DISTINCT ?position_statement) AS ?ministerCount)
WHERE 
{
  # Essere umano di cittadinanza italiana
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q5.
  ?item wdt:P27 wd:Q38.
  # Non più vecchio/a di Mattarella
  ?item wdt:P569 ?birth.
  filter (?birth > "1941-07-23"^^xsd:dateTime).
  filter (?birth < "1972-01-24"^^xsd:dateTime).
  # Non morto/a
  MINUS { ?item wdt:P570 ?death. }.
  # Ex parlamentari
  ?item wdt:P39/wdt:P361/wdt:P361 wd:Q1117578.
  MINUS {  ?item wdt:P39/wdt:P361/wdt:P361 wd:Q1117578 ; 
                 pq:P580 ?start FILTER (?start >= "2018-01-01T00:00:00Z"^^xsd:dateTime) . }
  # Ex ministri
  ?item p:P39 ?position_statement .
  ?position_statement ps:P39/wdt:P361 wd:Q3687318.
  # Ma non ministri recenti
  MINUS { ?item p:P39 ?position_recent .
         ?position_recent ps:P39/wdt:P361 wd:Q3687318.
         ?position_recent pq:P582 ?position_end
                   FILTER (?position_end >= "2014-01-01T00:00:00Z"^^xsd:dateTime). }
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],it". }
}
GROUP BY ?item ?itemLabel
context: Italian parliamentarians and ministers aged between 50 and 80
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct Italian individuals aged between 50 and 80 who are former parliamentarians and ministers. It filters out anyone deceased or currently serving since 2018 as parliamentarians or ministers after 2014. For each person, it counts how many ministerial roles they held, returning their name and the total number of ministerial positions.

context: Female Irish scientists in Wikidata without a Wikipedia article
target: This SPARQL query retrieves female Irish scientists from Wikidata who currently lack a Wikipedia article. It selects items that are humans (Q5), have Irish nationality (P27: Q27), are female (P21: Q6581072), and whose occupation (P106) is a scientist or subclass thereof (Q901). The query excludes any items already linked to a Wikipedia article and optionally fetches their occupation labels for display.

context: Places in the Hautes-Alpes that are the subject of an article on Wikipedia in at least 10 languages
target: This SPARQL query lists places located within the Hautes-Alpes region (wd:Q12709) that are not classified under several excluded types (like certain administrative units or protected areas). For each place, it retrieves its label, coordinates, an image if available, and counts how many Wikipedia language editions have articles about it. Only places featured in at least 10 language editions are shown, ordered by popularity.

query:
SELECT ?state ?stateLabel (COUNT(DISTINCT(?band)) AS ?bandCount)
  (GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT ?bandLabel; SEPARATOR=", ") AS ?bands)
WHERE {
  ?band p:P31 ?statement1.
  ?statement1 (ps:P31/(wdt:P279*)) wd:Q215380. # item is instance of musical group or subclass (ie. rock group)
  ?band p:P136 ?statement0.
  ?statement0 (ps:P136/(wdt:P279*)) wd:Q25554481. # band genre is punk music or subclass
  ?band wdt:P740 ?city. # band formed in city
  ?city wdt:P131* ?state. # county in admin body (state)
  ?state wdt:P31 wd:Q35657. # state is instance of US State
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en".
                         ?state rdfs:label ?stateLabel.
                          ?band rdfs:label ?bandLabel.}
  }
GROUP BY ?state ?stateLabel
ORDER BY DESC(?bandCount)
context: US states with the most punk bands
target: This SPARQL query retrieves US states ranked by the number of distinct punk music bands formed there. It identifies bands classified as musical groups with a punk genre, finds their formation cities, and traces those cities to their respective states. For each state, it counts the unique punk bands and lists their names, ordering results from states with the most punk bands to the least.

context: List of Ghanaian scientists by citation count
target: This SPARQL query lists Ghanaian scientists ranked by how often their works have been cited. It first identifies authors linked to Ghana by nationality, affiliation, or workplace. Then, for each author, it counts distinct citing works, selects a sample affiliated organization (based in Switzerland), and an example publication. Results include author and organization names, sorted by citation count, ideal for visualizing scientific impact.

query:
#productions of Pride and Prejudice and who played Elizabeth Bennet and what kind of thing they were
SELECT ?production ?productionLabel ?actress ?actressLabel (group_concat(?instanceofLabel ;separator=", ") as ?typeofproduction)

WHERE {
  
  ?production wdt:P144 wd:Q170583 ; # thing based on Pride & Prejudice
              p:P161 [ ps:P161 ?actress; pq:P453 wd:Q2223341 ] . # cast member has character role elizabeth bennet
       ?production wdt:P31 ?instanceof     
                               
    SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en".
                              ?instanceof rdfs:label ?instanceofLabel . # i don't know what this bit does except that it's needed
                            ?production rdfs:label ?productionLabel .
                            ?actress rdfs:label ?actressLabel .
                            
                         }
}

group by ?production ?productionLabel ?actress ?actressLabel
context: Actresses who have played Elizabeth Bennett in Pride and Prejudice, with type of production
target: This SPARQL query retrieves productions based on *Pride and Prejudice* where the character Elizabeth Bennet appears. For each production, it lists the production’s name, the actress who played Elizabeth Bennet, and the types of those productions (like film, TV series, or play). It groups and concatenates the production types for clarity, providing a clear overview of how Elizabeth Bennet has been portrayed across different media.

query:
# MPs with identified mythical ancestors
SELECT distinct ?person ?personLabel ?born ?died 
(group_concat(distinct ?classname;separator=", ") as ?class)  (count(distinct ?mp) as ?descendant_mp_count) WHERE {
  ?mp p:P39 ?positionStatement .
  ?positionStatement ps:P39 wd:Q77685926 .  # this person is a member of the current parliament
  { ?mp (wdt:P25|wdt:P22)* ?person . } # mp's mother or father, or their mother or father, and so on
  filter not exists { ?person wdt:P31 wd:Q5 } . # the ancestor is not "a human"
  ?person wdt:P31 ?type . ?type rdfs:label ?classname . filter(lang(?classname) = "en") .
  OPTIONAL { ?person wdt:P569 ?born } .
  OPTIONAL { ?person wdt:P570 ?died } .
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". }
} group by ?person ?personLabel ?born ?died order by ?personLabel
context: MPs with identified mythical ancestors
target: This SPARQL query finds current members of parliament (MPs) who have mythical ancestors—ancestors not classified as humans. It traces each MP’s lineage through parents recursively, identifies non-human ancestors, and gathers their types (like gods or legendary beings). The query returns these mythical ancestors with their birth/death dates, types, and counts how many MPs descend from each.

context: Timeline of 1st women practising a given sports discipline
target: This SPARQL query finds the earliest-born women practicing each sport profession. It first identifies all sports-related professions, then selects women athletes with birth dates and those professions. For each sport, it finds the minimum birth date, representing the "first" sportswoman. Finally, it returns these pioneering women, their professions, and birth dates, labeling them in English for a timeline view.

context: Water boards in the Netherlands
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all current water boards in the Netherlands, identified by the Wikidata class Q702081. It excludes any that have been dissolved (P576) or replaced (P1366), ensuring only active entities remain. The query also filters out those with an end date (P582) unless a matching start date (P580) without an end date exists, capturing ongoing water boards. Labels are returned in Dutch or English and results are ordered alphabetically.

query:
#title: Age of the actress when she played "Elizabeth Bennet"
#productions of Pride and Prejudice and who played Elizabeth Bennet and what kind of thing they were
SELECT DISTINCT ?production ?productionLabel ?actressLabel ?dateBirth ?dateProduction ?age WHERE {
  ?production wdt:P144 wd:Q170583 ;  # thing based on Pride & Prejudice
              p:P161 [ ps:P161 ?actress; pq:P453 wd:Q2223341 ] . # cast member has character role Elizabeth Bennet
  ?actress wdt:P569 ?dateBirth .
  ?production wdt:P577 ?dateProduction .
  BIND ( ((?dateProduction - ?dateBirth)/365.24) AS ?age )
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
}
ORDER BY ?age
context: Age of the actress when she played "Elizabeth Bennet"
target: This SPARQL query finds productions based on *Pride and Prejudice* where the character Elizabeth Bennet was played by an actress. It retrieves each production’s name, the actress’s name, their birth date, the production date, and calculates the actress’s age at that time by subtracting birth date from production date. Results are ordered by age.

query:
#title: people with dates of birth and death on January 1st (day precision dates)
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?itemDescription ?born ?died
{
  ?item p:P570 [ a wikibase:BestRank; psv:P570 [ wikibase:timeValue ?born; wikibase:timePrecision 11 ]] . 
  FILTER( MONTH(?born) = 1 && DAY(?born) = 1 ) 
  ?item p:P569 [ a wikibase:BestRank; psv:P569 [ wikibase:timeValue ?died; wikibase:timePrecision 11 ]] . 
  FILTER( MONTH(?died) = 1 && DAY(?died) = 1 ) 
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q5 .
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
}
LIMIT 1000
context: People with dates of birth and death on January 1st (day precision dates)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 1000 humans (instances of Q5) from Wikidata whose dates of birth and death both fall precisely on January 1st. It filters for records where the birth and death dates have day-level precision and extracts the item, its label, description, and exact birth and death dates, enabling exploration of individuals sharing this unique date pattern.

context: More than 500 lexemes in Breton now have at least one sense
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all distinct Breton lexemes that have at least one defined sense. For each lexeme, it gathers all unique lemmas (canonical forms) associated with it, concatenating them into a comma-separated list. The results are grouped by lexeme and ordered alphabetically by their lemmas, showcasing Breton's rich lexical data.

context: Events by number of video games announced
target: This SPARQL query retrieves events linked to video game announcements from Wikidata. It counts how many video games (instances of “video game”) are associated with each event via the property for announcement events (P9731). The results list each event with its label and the number of games announced there, ordered from the most to least announcements.

context: Three-Michelin Stars restaurants with a female chef
target: This SPARQL query finds up to 100 restaurants awarded three Michelin stars that currently hold this status (no end date on the award). It retrieves female chefs associated with these restaurants, either as employees in the chef role, as the creator, or as the owner, ensuring the chefs are identified as female. The query returns the chefs and their restaurants with labels in the user's language or English.

context: Countries with count of same Wikidata labels in different languages
target: This SPARQL query identifies countries (or states) that currently belong to the United Nations (wd:Q1065) and counts how many languages share the same label for each country. It filters out historical or dissolved states and labels without current membership. The query calculates the number of identical labels across languages, the total labels available, and the ratio of shared labels, showing how often a country's name is the same across different languages, ordered by the highest count.

context: Team and positions played by National Women's Football League players
target: This SPARQL query retrieves players from teams in the National Women's Football League, listing each player's team, name, position played, and the years they were active on that team. It uses detailed statements to capture the player's role and tenure, extracting start and end years if available. Results are labeled in English and sorted by team and player names.

query:
#defaultView:Map
SELECT  ?layer ?article ?person ?personLabel  ?personDescription  ?coord ?pic ?picGrave ?DoD
WHERE {
	?person wdt:P119 wd:Q311; #Place of burial
            p:P119 [ 
              pq:P965 ?graveplot;
              pq:P625 ?coord];
              wdt:P570 ?DoD.
   OPTIONAL{ ?person wdt:P18 ?pic .} 					# If we have an illustration
   OPTIONAL{ ?person wdt:P1442 ?picGrave .} 			# If we have a picture of the grave
   OPTIONAL {
      ?article schema:about ?person .
      ?article schema:inLanguage "fr" .
      ?article schema:isPartOf <https://fr.wikipedia.org/> .
    }
   OPTIONAL { ?person wdt:P21 ?group .} 			# Occupation in Layer

  #BIND(year(?DoD) AS ?Décès) 
  BIND(
    IF(?DoD < "1850-01-01T00:00:00Z"^^xsd:dateTime, "1800-1849",
    IF(?DoD < "1900-01-01T00:00:00Z"^^xsd:dateTime, "1850-1899",
    IF(?DoD < "1950-01-01T00:00:00Z"^^xsd:dateTime, "1900-1949",
    IF(?DoD < "2020-01-01T00:00:00Z"^^xsd:dateTime, "1950-2000",
    "2000-2022"))))
    AS ?layer).
  
#FILTER (YEAR(?DoD) >= 2000)
SERVICE wikibase:label {    bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "fr, en" .}

}
context: Location of the graves of personalities in Père Lachaise Cemetery who died between 1800 and 1849 (50 year ranges)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about notable people buried in Père Lachaise Cemetery (Q311), focusing on their grave locations, death dates, and related media. It groups individuals by their death period in 50-year intervals from 1800 to 2022, fetching coordinates, pictures of the person and their grave, and French Wikipedia articles when available. The results enable mapping graves by era.

context: Location of statues of women in Italy
target: This SPARQL query retrieves statues located in Italy that depict women. For each sculpture, it gathers the sculpture’s name, coordinates, an image (if available), and the name of the woman represented. It filters for sculptures classified as such, situated in Italy, and linked to a female person. The results enable mapping statues of women across Italy with labels and images.

context: Count of Lexeme pairs between different languages
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of different languages that share lexemes connected by the same meaning (sense) in Wikidata. It counts how many lexeme pairs exist between each language pair, excluding identical lexemes and languages. The query returns the top 100 language pairs with the most shared lexemes, along with their labels, ordered by descending count.

context: Birthplaces of General secretaries of USSR
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct individuals who are human (wd:Q5) and have held the position of General Secretary of the USSR (wd:Q1048744). For each person, it fetches their birthplace and geographic coordinates, along with their labels and descriptions in English. The results are ordered by the number of sitelinks, useful for mapping these birthplaces.

context: Items related to Abdülmecid I, their collections, and their types
target: This SPARQL query retrieves objects connected to Abdülmecid I (wd:Q174772), including images and labels. It finds items linked to him, their collections, and their types, organizing results by collection to group related objects. The query also fetches images and human-readable labels for the objects, collections, and relationships, providing a rich view of items associated with Abdülmecid I.

context: Objects related in some way to Aurangzeb
target: This SPARQL query retrieves objects connected to Aurangzeb (Q485547) in Wikidata. Starting from Aurangzeb, it finds items linked to him through various properties and groups them by their collections. For each object, it fetches images, labels, and the relationship type, also including images of the related collections. The result helps visualize how artifacts or items are associated with Aurangzeb.

context: Tram bridges in France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves tram bridges located in France from Wikidata. It selects distinct sites that are instances or subclasses of tram bridges (Q18615527), situated in France (Q142), and have geographic coordinates (P625). Additionally, it optionally fetches an image (P18) if available. Labels are returned in French or English, enabling map visualization.

context: Polish Righteous Among the Nations
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of Polish individuals recognized as Righteous Among the Nations. For each person, it fetches their name, birth and death dates (if available), and the dates they were honored. It also constructs a direct link to their Yad Vashem profile. The query groups multiple dates with "or" and ensures labels appear in the user's language or English.

context: Launch date, logo of social media services
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of social media platforms (instances of Q3220391) along with their labels in Indonesian or English. For each platform, it optionally fetches the launch date (P571) and extracts the launch year, the logo image (P154), the closure date (P582) with its year, and the official website (P856). The results are grouped by these attributes and intended for timeline visualization, highlighting launch and closure years.

context: Oscar winners from 1929
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Oscar-winning films and related details from Wikidata. It lists each awarded movie once per award category, showing the film, its director, the human recipient, the specific Academy Award edition, and the award type. It also includes the award date, ordering results from the newest to oldest Oscars, providing a snapshot of Oscar winners since 1929.

query:
#title:Biggest biologists ever
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT DISTINCT 
?person ?personLabel ?heigth_in_meters 
(SAMPLE(?pic) as ?image)
WHERE 
{
  ?person wdt:P106/wdt:P279* wd:Q864503 .
  ?person wdt:P31 wd:Q5 . 
  ?person wdt:P2048 ?height  . 
  OPTIONAL{?person wdt:P18 ?pic .} 
  ?person p:P2048 ?statement  .    
  ?statement       psv:P2048    ?valuenode .
  ?valuenode    wikibase:quantityAmount    ?value .
  ?valuenode    wikibase:quantityUnit  ?unit .
  
  ?unit p:P2370/psv:P2370 [                # conversion to SI unit
     wikibase:quantityAmount ?conversion;
     wikibase:quantityUnit wd:Q11573;      # meter
  ]
  BIND((?value * ?conversion) AS ?heigth_in_meters).
  

  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
GROUP BY ?person ?personLabel ?heigth_in_meters 
ORDER BY DESC(?heigth_in_meters)
context: Images of biologists by height
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of biologists (humans with the occupation "biologist" or its subclasses) along with their heights converted to meters. It optionally fetches their images and labels, then groups and orders them by height in descending order. The result is a ranked gallery of the tallest biologists, ideal for displaying images sorted by height.

query:
#title: Biggest coins outside the U.S.
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel ?pic ?diameter_in_cm ?country ?countryLabel ?material ?materialLabel
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P279* wd:Q41207 . 
  
  ?item wdt:P18 ?pic .
  ?item wdt:P17 ?country .
  MINUS {?item wdt:P17 wd:Q30 . }
  OPTIONAL{?item wdt:P186 ?material .}

  ?item p:P2386 ?statement_P2386  .    
  ?statement_P2386       psv:P2386    ?valuenode_P2386 .
  ?valuenode_P2386    wikibase:quantityAmount     ?value_P2386 .
  ?valuenode_P2386    wikibase:quantityUnit  ?unit_P2386 .


  ?unit_P2386 p:P2370/psv:P2370 [                # conversion to SI unit
     wikibase:quantityAmount ?conversion;
     wikibase:quantityUnit wd:Q11573;      # meter
  ]
  BIND((?value_P2386 * ?conversion)* 100 AS ?diameter_in_cm).
  
  
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
ORDER BY DESC(?diameter_in_cm)
context: Biggest coins outside the U.S.
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the largest coins from around the world, excluding those from the United States. It selects coins (and their images) with diameter measurements, converts these diameters into centimeters, and gathers related details like country of origin and material. Results are sorted by size, showing the biggest coins outside the U.S. with labels in your preferred language.

context: Frequency of letters in five-letter words in Wikidata lexeme forms
target: This SPARQL query analyzes five-letter English words from Wikidata lexemes to count how often each letter (a-z) appears in each position of these words. It first filters for English lexical entries with exactly five-letter forms, then iterates over each letter position, checking if the letter occurs there. Finally, it groups and orders letters by their total frequency across all positions.

context: Visualization of the Prime/Ulam Spiral using natural numbers and primes stored in Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query generates a list of natural numbers from 1 to 2000, excluding a specific anomalous number (0.999). For each number, it checks if it’s prime and assigns a color: red for primes and blue otherwise. Each number is given the same bubble size, preparing data to visualize the Prime/Ulam Spiral with colored bubbles representing primes and non-primes.

context: Monuments that are named after somebody without being connected to them by any other property
target: This SPARQL query finds monuments that are explicitly named after a person (using property P138) but have no other direct Wikidata property linking them to that person. It retrieves up to 100 such monuments, along with their labels, the person they’re named after, optional coordinates for mapping, and images if available—highlighting cases where naming is the sole connection.

context: Places named after Valentine's Day (Saint Valentine)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct places associated with Saint Valentine by selecting items (?q) that have geographic coordinates (?coord) and are linked to Valentine-related entities (?valentins). It fetches their labels in the user's language and displays the results on a map, effectively mapping locations named after or connected to Saint Valentine.

context: Gold medal winners in the Olympic Games by age
target: This SPARQL query retrieves gold medal winners in the Olympic Games, along with their sports, event dates, and ages at the time of winning. It filters out athletes born in the 19th century or with unknown birthdates. The event date is derived from multiple properties to handle inconsistent data, and age is roughly calculated by comparing birthdate and event date. Results are sorted by age.

context: Top 20 languages in number of lexemes in Wikidata and percentage of lexemes with at least one external id
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 20 languages on Wikidata by the number of lexemes they have. For each language, it counts total lexemes and how many have at least one external identifier linked. It then calculates the percentage of lexemes with external IDs, providing insight into the coverage and connectivity of lexical data across languages in Wikidata.

context: Count of PropertyLabels for lakes in the UK
target: This SPARQL query retrieves and counts distinct properties used to describe lakes located in the United Kingdom (UK) from Wikidata. Specifically, it targets items classified as lakes (wd:Q23397) with the country of location set to the UK (wd:Q145). For each property, it counts how many unique lakes have that property, fetches the property’s English label, and generates a URL linking to a detailed query showing all values for that property. The results are ordered by frequency, enabling visualization as a bar chart of the most common properties describing UK lakes.

query:
SELECT distinct ?planet ?planetLabel ?satellite ?satelliteLabel ?namedLabel ?namedDescription WHERE {
  ?planet wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q13205267.
  ?satellite wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q2537.
  ?satellite wdt:P397 ?planet.
  ?satellite wdt:P138 ?named.
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
  ?planet p:P2244/psv:P2244 ?statement.
      ?statement wikibase:quantityUnit ?unit.
      ?statement wikibase:quantityAmount ?distance.
      ?statement wikibase:quantityNormalized/wikibase:quantityAmount ?distanceNormalized. # convert to normalized unit (meter)
      BIND (?distanceNormalized / 9460800000000000  AS ?lightyears)
}
ORDER BY ?lightyears
context: Moons of solar system planets and what they are names for
target: This SPARQL query retrieves moons (satellites) orbiting planets within our solar system, along with details about what each moon is named after. It lists each planet and its moons, including labels and descriptions of the namesakes. Additionally, it fetches a specific measurement (property P2244), converts it to light-years, and orders the results by this distance, providing a structured view of moons and their name origins sorted by distance.

context: Top 20 languages in number of Lexemes in Wikidata and percentage of Lexemes with at least one external ID
target: This SPARQL query identifies the top 20 languages by the number of lexemes in Wikidata. For each language, it counts total lexemes and how many have at least one external identifier linked via specific properties. It then calculates the percentage of lexemes with external IDs, returning language names, counts, and these percentages, helping analyze language coverage and data completeness in Wikidata’s lexicographical data.

context: Successful coups and attempts in Africa
target: This SPARQL query retrieves coups and coup attempts in Africa by selecting items classified as coups, coup attempts, or related types. It filters for events in countries located on the African continent. Each event is labeled with its name, associated country, and date if available. The query also infers success by excluding coup attempts, then orders results by the most recent date.

context: New York Times journalists that are alive
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of living New York Times journalists. It selects distinct individuals whose occupation is journalist (wd:Q1930187) and who have a statement indicating employment at The New York Times (wd:Q9684). It excludes former employees (those with an end date for their NYT role) and deceased persons. For each journalist, it optionally fetches their date of birth and calculates their age. The results include the journalist’s name, birth date, and age, ordered by birth date descending.

query:
#title: Ukrainian coins and banknotes
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?pic
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P279* wd:Q693464 .
  ?item wdt:P17 wd:Q212 . 
  ?item wdt:P18 ?pic . 
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
context: Ukrainian coins and banknotes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves images of Ukrainian coins and banknotes from Wikidata. It selects items that are subclasses of currency (wd:Q693464) and are associated with Ukraine (wd:Q212). For each item, it fetches the item itself, its label in your language (or English), and an image, enabling a visual gallery of Ukrainian money.

context: Types of quartz
target: This SPARQL query retrieves different types of quartz from Wikidata. It finds all items that are subclasses (direct or indirect) of quartz (Q43010), along with their labels and images. The results include the item’s name and a picture, enabling a visual gallery of quartz varieties. The query adapts labels to your preferred language automatically.

context: Use of free software license for describing software
target: This SPARQL query counts how many software items use each free software license. It first finds licenses that are instances or subclasses of "free software license" and software instances or subclasses of "software" that use these licenses. Then, it groups the results by license name (in English) and orders them by the number of software items using each license, showing the most popular licenses first.

context: Count of latest available Twitter follower count for different programming languages
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the most recent Twitter follower counts for various programming languages. It first finds the latest date when follower data was recorded for each language, then fetches the follower count from that date. The result lists programming languages with their latest follower numbers, sorted from highest to lowest, ideal for visualizing popularity trends over time.

context: Timeline of programming languages and their paradigms
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of programming languages along with their associated paradigms. It selects programming languages (instances or subclasses of programming languages), their paradigms, and the year they were created or released. The results are labeled in English and ordered chronologically by year, providing a historical overview of programming languages and their paradigms.

context: Most popular programming language on Wikipedia with multilingual articles
target: This SPARQL query counts how many distinct Wikipedia languages have articles about various programming languages. It finds items classified as programming languages that have articles written in multiple languages. For each programming language, it counts the number of different Wikipedia language editions covering it, then lists those with more than 20 editions, ordered by popularity.

context: Places of birth of people named "Désirée"
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people named "Désirée" (wd:Q919943) along with their places of birth and geographic coordinates. It selects each person (?p), their place of birth (?pob), and the coordinates (?coor) of that place. Labels for these entities are also fetched in the user's language or English, enabling mapping of birthplaces on a map.

context: People in the Père-Lachaise cemetery who were born in a city that is or was in Ukraine
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about people buried in Père-Lachaise Cemetery (wd:Q311) who were born in cities located in Ukraine (wd:Q212). For each person, it fetches their name, description, birth and death dates, and the city of birth. The results are labeled in French or English and ordered by country and city names.

context: Properties linking between a church and its saint
target: This SPARQL query identifies and counts the properties that connect churches (instances of Q16970) to their associated saints, specifically saints linked to the Catholic Church (Q43115). It retrieves each property used in these relationships, along with its label, and shows how many churches use each property to reference their saint, helping analyze common linking attributes between churches and saints.

context: Properties describing Art UK artworks
target: This SPARQL query analyzes Wikidata properties used to describe Art UK artworks (items linked via property P1679). For each property, it counts distinct artworks and statements, selects sample items and values, and retrieves English labels. It excludes properties classified under unique identifiers or authority control, then orders results by artwork and statement counts, highlighting the most descriptive properties.

context: Timeline of victims of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of victims related to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. It selects items linked to a specific event (Q110999040), fetching their death dates, associated countries (excluding those with USSR citizenship to avoid duplicates), and images if available. The results include labels in multiple languages and are ordered by date, enabling a clear chronological view.

context: Population of countries that share a border with Russia
target: This SPARQL query retrieves countries that share a land border with Russia (wd:Q159) and are currently members of the Commonwealth of Independent States (wd:Q1065). For each such country, it fetches the country’s name and its population (wdt:P1082). It excludes countries whose membership ended (using a filter on the membership end date). Labels are returned in the user's language or English.

context: Audio pronunciation of places in Wales
target: This SPARQL query retrieves places in Wales (Q25) along with their audio pronunciations and geographic coordinates.
