It selects entities located directly in Wales or nested within administrative divisions of Wales. For each place, it fetches the audio pronunciation (P443), location coordinates (P625), and the place name in Welsh, enabling a map view with Welsh labels and audio clips.

context: Things with a national gallery of Scotland ID where the artist was or is a woman
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all artworks that have a National Gallery of Scotland ID and were created by a female artist. For each artwork, it fetches the item’s label, the National Gallery ID, and links to the artwork’s and artist’s Wikipedia pages (if available). It also includes the artist’s name, focusing specifically on women creators.

context: Software with gender information of developer, designer and the person named after
target: This SPARQL query counts distinct software developers, designers, or individuals after whom software is named, grouped by their gender. It first identifies all such people linked to software items, then filters them by specific gender types. Finally, it returns the number of unique individuals per gender, displaying labels for readability—ideal for visualizing gender distribution in software creation roles.

context: Signature images from Wikidata (change the view to “map” to see the signatures arranged by the person’s place of birth!
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 human individuals from Wikidata, along with one of their signature images and, if available, the coordinates of their place of birth. It samples signature images to avoid duplicates and filters for humans only. The results include labels and can be visualized as an image grid or on a map by birthplace, enabling exploration of signatures geographically.

context: Count of UK lake items with a 'UK Lakes Portal ID' (P7548) property statement
target: This SPARQL query counts UK lake items in Wikidata based on whether they have a 'UK Lakes Portal ID' (property P7548). It selects items that are instances or subclasses of lakes (Q23397) located in the UK (country Q145). The query groups results into two categories: lakes with a UK Lakes Portal ID ("WBID") and those without ("No WBID"), returning counts for each group.

context: Timeline for the Apple "M" series of Systems on a Chip (SoC)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of Apple’s "M" series SoCs by selecting each chip (?item) that is part of the M series (wd:Q101791498). For each chip, it fetches the item’s label (?itemLabel), an image (?img), and its announcement date (?ann_date). The results include readable labels in the user’s language or English, ideal for visualizing the M series evolution.

context: Religion of men named “Maria” (as one of their given names)
target: This SPARQL query counts the number of men named “Maria” grouped by their religion using Wikidata. It finds items with the given name “Maria” (wd:Q25413386) and gender male (wd:Q6581097), then retrieves their associated religions (P140). The results show each religion’s label and how many men named Maria follow it.

context: Shortest rail link between Narvik and Singapore (passing through Finland and Kazakhstan
target: This SPARQL query finds the shortest rail connection between Narvik (Norway) and Singapore by using a breadth-first search (BFS) over rail stations in Wikidata. It retrieves each intermediate station along this path, excluding Narvik itself, and constructs geographic line segments between consecutive stations using their latitude and longitude. The result includes station names and geospatial data, enabling visualization of the rail route on a map.

context: Map of institutions where "where people who studied there" have created written works whose main subject is knowledge graph (Q33002955), knowledge base (Q515701) and (Q33002955)
target: This SPARQL query finds written works focused on knowledge graphs, knowledge bases, or related topics. It identifies the authors of these works and the institutions where the authors studied. Finally, it retrieves the geographic coordinates of these institutions to map their locations. The query also fetches labels for items, authors, and institutions for easy reading.

context: Colonies of Africa with their or their “main state”’s official language and ISO code
target: This SPARQL query retrieves African colonies (entities classified as colonies located in Africa) along with their official languages and the languages’ ISO codes. It checks for colonies either directly linked to a language or via their “main state.” The results include colony names, language names, and ISO codes, sorted by the ISO code for easy reference.

context: Wikidata knowledge graph of Elizabeth Keckley, dressmaker to U.S. First Lady Mary Todd Lincoln
target: This SPARQL query retrieves pairs of specific Wikidata items from a predefined list, along with the properties (edges) that connect them. For each item pair (?item1 and ?item2), it finds any direct relationship (?prop) linking them, fetches their labels and images if available, and also gets the label of the connecting property. This helps visualize relationships within a focused subset of the Wikidata graph.

context: Women who served as defense ministers in various countries
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data about women who have served as defense ministers. It selects female human individuals (?menteri) with positions (?jabatan) classified under defense ministers. For each, it fetches labels in Indonesian or English, their country, images, and their term period formatted as "start year - end year" or "start year - sekarang" if ongoing. The results support an image grid view.

context: UK MPs who had paired names (e.g. Owen Thomas / Thomas Owen)
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of UK Members of Parliament (MPs) whose first and family names appear swapped between two individuals—for example, one named "Owen Thomas" and another "Thomas Owen." It retrieves these MPs, their labels, and links to their English Wikipedia articles, highlighting cases of name inversion among MPs in specific parliamentary memberships.

context: List of properties associated with items that are class/subclass of File Format
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all unique properties linked to items that are instances or subclasses of the "File Format" class (Q235557) in Wikidata. It finds properties used to describe these items, then fetches their English labels for readability. Finally, it orders the properties alphabetically by their labels, providing a clear overview of attributes related to file formats.

context: Table frequency of properties used in instances of public libraries
target: This SPARQL query lists properties used in items classified as public libraries (wd:Q28564). It first selects all such library items, then counts how often each property appears across them. Next, it links these properties to their human-readable labels. Finally, it returns each property, its label, and usage count, ordered by frequency, revealing the most common attributes describing public libraries.

context: Long swedish / german nouns in Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 1000 unique Swedish and German nouns from Wikidata, focusing on their lexical entries. It selects each word’s label and calculates its length in characters. The results are ordered by word length in descending order, highlighting the longest nouns in these two languages.

query:
#title: Most popular chess openings 
#defaultView:BubbleChart
SELECT
  ?item ?itemLabel 
  ((?sitelinks * ?sitelinks) as ?links_squared)
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q103632 .
  ?item wikibase:sitelinks ?sitelinks . 
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". }
}
ORDER BY
  DESC (?sitelinks)
context: Most popular Chess openings (by number of sitelinks)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the most popular chess openings from Wikidata, identified as instances of the class "chess opening" (Q103632). For each opening, it fetches its label and the number of Wikipedia sitelinks, which indicate how many language versions cover it. It also calculates the square of sitelinks to emphasize popularity, then orders results by descending sitelinks count, ideal for a bubble chart visualization.

context: Wikimedia affiliates on social media
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Wikimedia affiliate entities classified under specific types (Q22337472, Q15924535, Q24524653). For each affiliate (?item), it fetches properties (?property) that have a formatter pattern (P1630) defined. It then constructs URLs by combining the formatter template with the property's value. The results include the item, its label, the property label, and the generated URL, all ordered by the affiliate's name. This helps map social media or related links dynamically for Wikimedia affiliates.

context: Listed viaducts in the UK
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of UK viaducts from Wikidata. It selects each viaduct’s item, name, designation type, image (if available), an identifier, and geographic coordinates. The query filters items classified as viaducts (Q181348) or their subclasses, includes various ID properties, and fetches labels in the user’s language or English. Results are ordered alphabetically by name, ideal for mapping or cataloging these structures.

context: Pages linked to the University of Clermont according to the number of articles on Wikimedia projects
target: This SPARQL query retrieves entities linked to four specific universities in Clermont by counting how many distinct Wikimedia pages reference each entity. It filters for entities connected to these universities, gathers their labels and descriptions, and only shows those referenced by more than one page. Results are ordered by the highest number of linked pages, highlighting prominent topics related to these universities.

context: Which languages share a word for the same thing (visualized as a tree map). e.g. planet
target: This SPARQL query finds words (lemmas) in different languages that share the same meaning, specifically for the concept identified by Wikidata item Q634 (e.g., "planet"). It retrieves the lemma and its language, enabling a visualization like a tree map to compare how various languages name the same concept. Labels are fetched in the user's language or English.

context: Birthplace of rappers
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of rappers, their birthplaces, and pictures from Wikidata. It selects items classified as rappers (P106 = Q2252262), fetches their birthplace (P19), and obtains the geographic coordinates (P625) of those birthplaces. Labels and images are included for easy display, enabling a map visualization of rappers’ birth locations.

context: Bubble chart of occupation of people linked to University of Clermont
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the occupations of people associated with four universities in Clermont by counting distinct researchers linked through employment, membership, or academic affiliation. It groups results by occupation labels, producing data ideal for a bubble chart that visualizes the diversity and number of professionals connected to these institutions.

context: List of corporate archives, location, and address where available
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of corporate archives from Wikidata, including their names, opening dates, countries, geographic coordinates, websites, and addresses when available. It uses optional clauses to include data only if present and fetches labels in multiple languages for better readability. This helps compile detailed info about corporate archives worldwide.

context: French adventure video games
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of French adventure video games from Wikidata. For each game, it finds the earliest publication year, along with its developers, publishers, and platforms. It gathers all related labels in French (or the user's language) and orders the results by the first publication date, providing a clear overview of French adventure games and their key details.

context: Women with the citizenship of a country and the most articles in other languages (including English) but without an article in French Wikipedia
target: This SPARQL query retrieves women (humans, P31=Q5; gender female, P21=Q6581072) who hold citizenship of Chile (P27=Q235). It finds Wikipedia sitelinks about these women, counting distinct sitelinks per item, but only includes those with an English Wikipedia article and no French Wikipedia article. Results are grouped and ordered by the number of sitelinks, showing women with the most multilingual coverage excluding French.

context: Top 100 lexemes with the most number of senses
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 100 lexemes with the most senses from a linguistic dataset. It counts how many senses each lexeme has, orders them by this count, and then fetches their language, labels, and all associated lemmas (word forms) concatenated into a string. The result lists lexemes by descending sense count, showing language and lemma details for each.

context: Given a language and a country, show a map of the demonyms in that language that are used in any part within that country
target: This SPARQL query retrieves demonyms (words for residents) in a specified language that are associated with locations within a given country. It finds lexemes in the chosen language whose meanings link to places inside the country, then fetches their geographic coordinates. The results include the demonym, its location, and labels, enabling visualization on a map.

context: Most common classes for values of "depicts" (P180) on Commons
target: This SPARQL query identifies the most common Wikidata classes for items depicted in Wikimedia Commons images. It samples 4,000 random files with a "depicts" (P180) property, counts how often each depicted item appears, then groups these items by their classes (P31). Finally, it ranks classes by total depiction count, providing example items and labels to illustrate common subjects in Commons media.

context: Scottish river drainage basins
target: This SPARQL query retrieves drainage basins of Scottish rivers and their key features for mapping. It first identifies geographic entities within Scotland (Q22) linked to seas via specific properties. Then, it filters out entities classified as watercourses, lakes, or unrelated water bodies, focusing on estuaries and channels. Finally, it selects river layers and related points (dots) with geographic coordinates, enabling visualization of river basins and their connections to seas on a map.

context: The earliest road accident victims
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct humans (wd:Q5) who died due to road accidents (wdt:P509 wd:Q9687), along with their labels, descriptions, and date of death (wdt:P570). It uses the Wikibase label service to get names and descriptions in English or Dutch, then orders the results by the earliest date of death, highlighting the earliest recorded road accident victims.

context: Country of nationality of people linked to the Ghana's top 3 traditional universities
target: This SPARQL query identifies the countries of nationality and their continents for people associated with Ghana's top three traditional universities. It counts distinct researchers linked to these universities through employment, membership, or affiliation. The results show how many individuals from each country and continent are connected to these institutions, providing insight into their international reach.

context: Count of Wikidata property types
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the count of distinct Wikidata properties grouped by their property types. It selects each property type (`?propType`) and counts how many unique properties (`?prop`) belong to that type. The results are grouped by property type and ordered in descending order, showing the most common property types first.

query:
#title: Languages and dialects with number of first language speakers (preferred rank)
#credit: https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:Request_a_query#Languages_by_number_of_native_speakers_at_point_in_time
SELECT DISTINCT (?item AS ?QNumber) ?P220 ?LanguageLabel ?P1098 ?Qualifier_P585
WHERE
{
  VALUES ?instance_of { wd:Q34770 wd:Q33384 } # Language or dialect
  ?item wdt:P31 ?instance_of .
  OPTIONAL { ?item wdt:P220 ?P220 . } # ISO 639 3 code
  ?item p:P1098 ?no_of_speakers_statement .
  ?no_of_speakers_statement wikibase:rank wikibase:PreferredRank . # Has preferred rank
  ?no_of_speakers_statement pq:P518 wd:Q36870 . # Has the qualifier applies to part = first language
  ?no_of_speakers_statement ps:P1098 ?P1098 . # No of speakers
  OPTIONAL { ?no_of_speakers_statement pq:P585 ?Qualifier_P585 . } # Optional timestamp
  SERVICE wikibase:label
  {
    bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en" .
    ?item rdfs:label ?LanguageLabel .
  }
}
ORDER BY DESC(?P1098)
context: Languages and dialects with number of first language speakers (preferred rank)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves languages and dialects from Wikidata along with their ISO 639-3 codes, number of native speakers, and optional timestamps. It filters for entries with a preferred rank for the number of first-language speakers, ensuring data quality. Results include labels in English and are sorted by descending number of native speakers, highlighting the most widely spoken languages.

context: Graph of influences in the age of Enlightenment
target: This SPARQL query retrieves pairs of people where one influenced the other during the Age of Enlightenment. It selects individuals (?a) born between 1590 and 1750 and finds whom they influenced (?b), ensuring both are humans. The query returns their names and IDs, enabling visualization of intellectual influences in that historical period.

context: Countries which are named after a person
target: This SPARQL query retrieves countries named after a person, directly or indirectly (up to two levels of naming). It excludes countries named after saints or biblical figures to focus on secular individuals. The results list each country alongside the person it’s named after, providing labels for easy reading, ordered alphabetically by the person's name.

context: Number of musical works (compositions) in Wikidata by language, in descending order
target: This SPARQL query counts musical works (instances of Q105543609) in Wikidata, grouping them by their language of expression (property P407). It retrieves the language label and orders the results by the number of works in descending order, showing which languages have the most compositions. The optional clause ensures works without a specified language are included with a null value.

context: List of French public administrations with an open data portal, a siren number (P1616) and a servicepublic id (P6671)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves French public administrations that have a Service Public directory ID, a SIREN code, and an associated open data portal on Wikidata. For each administration, it fetches its name, constructs the directory URL using the ID, and obtains the open data portal’s name and URL. Labels are filtered to match the user’s language.

query:
#title:Largest cities with female mayor
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT DISTINCT ?mayorImage ?mayor ?mayorLabel ?city ?cityLabel ?population
{
  ?city (wdt:P31/(wdt:P279*)) wd:Q515;
    p:P6 ?statement.
  ?statement ps:P6 ?mayor.
  ?mayor wdt:P21 wd:Q6581072.
  FILTER(NOT EXISTS { ?statement pq:P582 ?x. })
  ?mayor wdt:P18 ?mayorImage.
  ?city wdt:P1082 ?population.
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". }
}
ORDER BY DESC (?population)
LIMIT 30
context: Largest cities with a female mayor
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the 30 largest cities currently led by a female mayor. It finds cities (instances of “city”) with a mayor (property P6) who is female (gender P21 = female). It ensures the mayor is currently in office by filtering out those with an end date (P582). For each mayor, it fetches their image, name, and the city’s name and population, then orders results by city population in descending order.

context: Reach of Twitter accounts on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Twitter accounts linked to Wikidata items along with their subscriber counts. It looks for statements using property P2002 (Twitter username) and fetches the qualifier P3744, which records the number of subscribers. Results are ordered from the highest to lowest subscriber count, highlighting the most followed Twitter accounts on Wikidata.

context: Which works published in the 1970s have been most cited from works on archaeology?
target: This SPARQL query finds the top 10 most cited works published in the 1970s that are referenced by archaeological research. It identifies works related to archaeology (Q23498) through various property paths, counts how often each cited work appears in those archaeological works, filters for cited works published between 1970 and 1979, and returns their titles and citation counts, sorted by popularity.

context: List of oldest cryptocurrencies
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 cryptocurrencies (instances of the class Q13479982) from Wikidata, along with their inception dates (P571). For each, it calculates the approximate age in years by subtracting the inception date from the current date. Results are ordered by their start date, showing the oldest cryptocurrencies first, with labels in English.

context: Scottish rivers that merge to make a river with a new name
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of Scottish rivers that merge (confluence) to form a new river with a different name. It selects each watercourse and the river it merges with, ensuring the pair is unique by filtering order. Additionally, it retrieves the river that the original watercourse flows into ("gives rise to"). Labels for all rivers are included for readability.

context: List of candidates in the French legislative elections
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 100 human entities (wd:Q5) linked to the French legislative elections (wd:Q106253677) as candidates (P3602). It counts how many Wikipedia pages mention each candidate, optionally grouping by their electoral district (circo). Labels are fetched in French and English, and results are ordered by the number of mentions, highlighting prominent candidates and their constituencies.

context: List of people with Elisabeth, Élisabeth or Elizabeth  as first name
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 human entities (wd:Q5) whose first name (property P735) matches one of three specific Wikidata items representing Elisabeth, Élisabeth, or Elizabeth. It counts how many matching name statements each person has, prioritizing those with a rank less than 2 (usually preferred or normal rank). It only includes items with Wikipedia pages (in French or English) and fetches their labels and descriptions in these languages, ordering results by the count of matching names in descending order.

context: Wikimedians with a Twitch channel
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Wikimedians—people involved with Wikimedia projects—who are also Twitch streamers. It selects individuals (instances of human) with the occupation "Wikimedian" and a Twitch username. The query constructs their Twitch channel URL by appending the username to "https://www.twitch.tv/". Results include the person's name and their Twitch URL, sorted alphabetically by the URL.

context: Relationships of Roman deities
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Roman deities and their related figures, such as children or connected individuals, along with their images. It selects entities classified as Roman deities (wd:Q11688446), finds their related persons through parent-child or other family links, and fetches labels and images for both the deity and their associated figures. The results help visualize family relationships among Roman gods.

context: Ingrediants of dishes on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves dishes from Wikidata along with their ingredients. It selects items classified as dishes (wd:Q746549) and lists their components (ingredients). For each dish, it counts the unique ingredients and concatenates their names into a comma-separated string. Results are grouped by dish and sorted by the number of ingredients in descending order, showing dishes with the most ingredients first.

query:
#defaultView:Map
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel ?place ?placeLabel ?coords ?img ?layer WHERE {
  ?item wdt:P31?/wdt:P279* wd:Q2095 .
  ?item wdt:P138 ?place .
  ?place wdt:P17 wd:Q145 .
  ?place wdt:P131 [] .
  OPTIONAL {?place wdt:P625 ?coords} .
  OPTIONAL {?item wdt:P18 ?img} .
  
  OPTIONAL {?item wdt:P31?/wdt:P279*  wd:Q10943 . BIND (wd:Q10943 AS ?type)} .
  OPTIONAL {?item wdt:P31?/wdt:P279*  wd:Q3314483 . BIND (wd:Q3314483 AS ?type)} .
  OPTIONAL {?item wdt:P31?/wdt:P279*  wd:Q40050 . BIND (wd:Q40050 AS ?type)} .
  OPTIONAL {BIND (wd:Q2095 AS ?type)} .
  OPTIONAL {?type rdfs:label ?layer . FILTER(lang(?layer) = 'en')}
            
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". }
} ORDER BY ?itemLabel
context: Food names after a place in the UK
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct food items (wd:Q2095) linked to places within the UK (wd:Q145). For each food item, it fetches the item's label, associated place and its label, geographic coordinates if available, and an image if present. It also categorizes items into types like dish (wd:Q10943), food product (wd:Q3314483), or ingredient (wd:Q40050), labeling these types as layers. The results are ordered alphabetically by the food item’s name.

context: French heads of government classified by tenure
target: This SPARQL query retrieves French heads of government (human individuals) who began their terms after January 1, 1800. It lists each person (?item) along with their role (?position), the start date of their tenure (?start), and optional additional functions (?fonction). Results are ordered by the most recent start dates and names, showing up to 10,000 entries with labels in the user's language or English.

context: Places in Antarctica over 3000km away from the South Pole
target: This SPARQL query finds places located in Antarctica that are more than 3000 kilometers away from the South Pole. It first retrieves the coordinates of the South Pole, then selects places on the Antarctic continent with their geographic coordinates. Using a distance filter, it returns only those places whose locations exceed 3000 km from the South Pole, along with their names and coordinates, ideal for mapping.

context: Topics that members of the Swedish Parliament motioned about 2020/21
target: This SPARQL query retrieves topics (items) that members of the Swedish Parliament (Riksdag, Q99037794) motioned about during the 2020/21 period. For each parliament member (?item1), it fetches their political party's color (?rgb). It also gets the related topic (?item2) they addressed, along with labels in English and Swedish. This helps visualize which topics were raised by which members and their party affiliations.

context: Albums with more than one language statement where none has preferred rank
target: This SPARQL query retrieves albums (instances of "album") that have multiple language statements (P407) but none marked with a preferred rank. It selects distinct albums with at least two different language entries, ensuring no language is designated as preferred. Labels are fetched in the user's language or English for readability.

context: List of candidates for the next French legislative elections
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of candidates (humans) participating in the next French legislative elections (property P3602 with value Q106253677). For each candidate, it fetches their name, the constituency they are running in, their political party, and the number of votes received, if available. Results are ordered by constituency name in descending order, with labels shown in English.

context: Occupation of people named Elizabeth, Élisabeth or Elisabeth in Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query finds the top 20 occupations of people named Elizabeth, Élisabeth, or Elisabeth in Wikidata. It looks for humans (wd:Q5) whose given name (P735) matches any of these three name entries (Q385468, Q17524931, Q18093037). It counts how many individuals have each occupation (P106), considering only those with a name rank less than 2 (to prioritize primary names). Results are grouped by occupation and labeled in English, sorted by count descending.

context: Timeline of the start of pride parades from 1970
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of pride parades by selecting items that are instances or subclasses of "pride parade" (wd:Q51404). For each parade, it fetches the start date (wdt:P571) and optionally an image (wdt:P18) if available. This data can be used to visualize when various pride parades began, starting from 1970.

query:
#defaultView:BubbleChart
#title: Top 10 genes associated with most diseases on Wikidata
SELECT 
  ?item ?itemLabel        
  (COUNT(DISTINCT ?disease) AS ?n_diseases)

WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q7187 . 
  
  ?disease wdt:P2293|^wdt:P2293 ?item.

  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
GROUP BY
  ?item ?itemLabel
ORDER BY
  DESC (?n_diseases)
LIMIT 20
context: Top 100 genes with most genetic associations on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the top 20 genes linked to the highest number of distinct diseases in Wikidata. It selects items classified as genes (wd:Q7187) and counts how many diseases are associated with each gene via the genetic association property (wdt:P2293). Results are grouped by gene and sorted to highlight those with the most disease connections, displaying their labels for easy identification.

context: Biennales that aren’t biennial
target: This SPARQL query searches Wikidata for items with "biennale" in their English label, aiming to find biennales that do not occur every two years. It retrieves events labeled as biennales but filters out those with a 2-year interval, thus identifying biennales held at intervals other than biennial. The query returns the item and its label for easy reference.

context: Which are the most popular natural products based on the number of statements on their corresponding QID?
target: This SPARQL query identifies the most popular natural products by counting the number of statements linked to their Wikidata items (QIDs). It focuses on entities classified as chemical compounds or related chemical groups found in specific taxa, using taxonomic data as a proxy for natural origin. Only items with over 100 statements are included, and results are sorted by statement count in descending order, highlighting well-documented natural products.

context: Occupation of people named Elizabeth, Elisabeth or Élisabeth
target: This SPARQL query finds the top 20 occupations held by people named Elizabeth, Elisabeth, or Élisabeth in Wikidata. It looks for human items (?item) with these given names (?target) and retrieves their occupations (?occupation). It counts how many individuals share each occupation, considering only the primary or secondary name rank (rank < 2). Results are labeled in English and sorted by popularity.

context: Thomas Telford's different alleged associations with buildings, according to wikidata statements
target: This SPARQL query analyzes Thomas Telford's various claimed roles related to buildings in Wikidata. It first finds all building items linked to Telford (Q380875) via any property, then identifies those properties’ English labels. Next, it groups these labels per building into combined roles. Finally, it counts how many distinct buildings share each role combination, ranking them by frequency to reveal Telford’s most common associations with buildings.

context: items with senses in the most languages on Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query finds items on Wikidata that have lexical senses represented in the greatest number of distinct languages. It counts how many languages each item’s senses appear in (requiring more than two), then retrieves example languages, lemmas, and sample lexemes and senses. Results are ordered by the number of languages, highlighting multilingual lexical diversity.

context: A & B roads carried on Scottish bridges
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct Scottish bridges located within London (wd:Q22) that carry specific road segments (A & B roads). It selects each bridge, its related road segment (?item), and their labels. The query also fetches the bridge’s coordinates and associated road layers, ordering results by the number of Wikipedia sitelinks, helping identify notable bridges carrying these roads.

context: Timeline of Rafael Nadal awards and nominations
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of Rafael Nadal’s awards and nominations from Wikidata, focusing on Spanish labels. It fetches distinct events (?o) with their dates (?fecha) and Spanish descriptions (?denominacion). It combines two properties: nominations (P1344) and awards received (P166), optionally including event dates (P585), and orders the results chronologically for a clear timeline view.

context: Articles studying chemicals from the oceans
target: This SPARQL query retrieves unique chemical compounds found in various marine organisms—such as fishes, cyanobacteria, red algae, green algae, sponges, and corals—and the scientific articles reporting them. It identifies compounds linked to these organisms, extracts their chemical structures (SMILES format), and fetches article references with DOIs, providing a comprehensive view of marine natural products and their literature sources.

context: Municipalities of France, by their population and their altitude
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 French municipalities, fetching each one's population and altitude. It calculates a new value by multiplying population by altitude, then orders the results descendingly by this value. The query excludes any municipalities with a recorded end date, ensuring only current entities are considered, and includes labels in the preferred language for readability.

query:
SELECT ?person ?personLabel ?spouse ?spouseLabel ?grandparent ?grandparentLabel ?linkcount WHERE {
    ?person wdt:P31 wd:Q5 . # en människa
    ?person wdt:P26 ?spouse .
    ?person wdt:P569 ?date .
    FILTER(datatype(?date)=xsd:dateTime
           && ?date >= "1800-01-01T00:00:00"^^xsd:dateTime)
    ?person wikibase:sitelinks ?linkcount .
    ?spouse wikibase:sitelinks ?spouselinkcount .
    FILTER (?linkcount >= ?spouselinkcount) # för att inte få paren två gånger (utom när lika "kända")
    ?parent wdt:P40 ?person .
    ?grandparent wdt:P40 ?parent .
    ?spouseparent wdt:P40 ?spouse .
    ?grandparent wdt:P40 ?spouseparent .
    ?person wikibase:sitelinks ?linkcount . # hur sortera på t.ex. summa av linkcount?
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "sv,en,de,fr" }
}
GROUP BY  ?linkcount ?person ?personLabel ?spouse ?spouseLabel ?grandparent ?grandparentLabel
ORDER BY DESC(?linkcount)
context: In cousin marriages (born 1800 and later)
target: This SPARQL query finds people born from 1800 onward who are married to someone sharing the same grandparent—indicating cousin marriages. It retrieves each person, their spouse, and their shared grandparent, along with labels in multiple languages. To avoid duplicate pairs, it only includes couples where the person has equal or more Wikipedia sitelinks than their spouse, sorting results by the person’s notability.

context: Actors who played the same real politician the most times
target: This SPARQL query finds actors who have portrayed the same real-life politician in multiple films. It counts distinct films where an actor played a character identified as a human with a political position, excluding cases where actor and character are the same entity. The top 100 actor-character pairs with more than one film are returned, showing who repeatedly played which politician.

query:
#defaultView:ImageGrid
#title: Most famous heritage locations of the world (measured by sitelinks)
SELECT DISTINCT
  ?item ?itemLabel ?sitelinks (SAMPLE(?pic) as ?sample_pic)
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P1435 [] . 
  ?item wikibase:sitelinks ?sitelinks . hint:Prior hint:rangeSafe true.
  FILTER (?sitelinks > 50) 
  
  ?item wdt:P18 ?pic .
  ?item rdfs:label ?itemLabel . 
  FILTER (LANG (?itemLabel) = "en")
}
GROUP BY ?item ?itemLabel ?sitelinks
ORDER BY DESC(?sitelinks)
context: Most famous heritage locations (measured by sitelinks)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the most famous heritage locations worldwide, ranked by their popularity on Wikidata. It selects items classified as heritage sites (with property P1435), having more than 50 sitelinks—indicating wide coverage across Wikimedia projects. For each, it fetches the English label, the number of sitelinks, and a sample image, displaying them ordered from most to least linked.

context: Islands with at least 1 spring or freshwater body
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct islands along with their labels, countries, sizes, coordinates, and related freshwater bodies. It selects islands (wd:Q23442) with known area (P2046), country (P17), and coordinates (P625). It also finds freshwater features (landwaters) located on these islands, ensuring these features are types of springs or freshwater bodies (subclasses of wd:Q863944). Results are ordered by island size, with labels shown in the user's language or English.

context: Notable people who you share a birthday with (find the string "1966-08-25" and replace it with your date of birth)
target: This SPARQL query finds notable people who share your birthday (here, August 25, 1966). It looks up entities born on that date, retrieves their Wikipedia article titles, labels, descriptions, and the number of Wikipedia sitelinks. It also prepares a cleaned-up version of their names for sorting, ignoring common surname prefixes. Results are ordered alphabetically by this processed name and then by the original label.

context: List of filmmakers with whom Jean-Louis Trintignant has played
target: This SPARQL query finds directors who have worked on films starring Jean-Louis Trintignant (wd:Q106204). It selects each director (?director) along with their name (?directorLabel) and counts how many such films they directed (?count). Results are grouped by director and sorted to show those with the most collaborations first, highlighting Trintignant’s frequent filmmakers.

context: Cemeteries in France near churches
target: This SPARQL query finds cemeteries in France (wd:Q142) and lists nearby churches within a 0.02-degree radius. It retrieves each cemetery's and church's names and calculates the distance between them. The query ensures the places are correctly typed (cemeteries and churches) and uses Wikidata’s geocoordinates and label services for precise location and multilingual labels.

context: Graph of fictional wars and their participants
target: This SPARQL query builds a graph linking fictional wars to their fictional universes and participants. It first connects each fictional war (Q17198419) to its related universe, franchise, or work, coloring these links yellow ("F7FF00"). Then, it links participants involved in these wars to the wars themselves, coloring these edges green ("7FFF00"). Labels are fetched for readability.

context: The 100 most common species as subjects of publications known to Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query finds the top 100 species most frequently studied in publications recorded in Wikidata. It counts how many publications mention each species as a topic, filters for items classified as species, and retrieves their scientific names. The results list species with their publication counts, ordered from most to least referenced.

context: Map of birthplaces of ASM Clermont Auvergne players
target: This SPARQL query retrieves birthplaces of ASM Clermont Auvergne rugby players. It selects each player’s name, birthplace, birthdate, geographic coordinates of the birthplace, a time-based layer grouping players by birth decade, and optionally their image. The results enable mapping players’ birth locations, grouped by birth decade, with labels in the user’s language.

context: Number of albums in Wikidata by language, in descending order
target: This SPARQL query counts how many albums (items classified as Q482994) exist in Wikidata for each language (property P407). It groups albums by their language and orders the results by the number of albums in descending order, showing the language label alongside. This helps identify which languages have the most albums documented in Wikidata.

query:
#defaultView:BubbleChart
SELECT  ?ocu ?ocuLabel  (COUNT(DISTINCT ?item) AS ?count)
(SAMPLE(?ocu) as ?ocu_sampled)
where {
  hint:Query hint:optimizer "None".
  ?item wdt:P2966 ?llgc .
  ?item wdt:P106 ?ocu .
?ocu wdt:P279+ wd:Q639669 .
 
 SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } 
} 
GROUP BY ?ocu ?ocuLabel
ORDER BY DESC(?count) ?ocuLabel
context: Occupation about musicians in Wales
target: This SPARQL query counts distinct items (e.g., people) associated with various occupations linked to musicians in Wales. It selects items having a specific identifier (P2966) and an occupation (P106) that is a subclass of "musician" (Q639669). The results group occupations by label, showing how many unique items belong to each, ordered by count descending.

context: Map of tram depots in France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a map of tram depots located in France. It selects distinct sites classified as tram depots, ensures they are within France, and fetches their geographic coordinates. Additionally, it optionally includes images of these sites. The results are labeled in French, making it ideal for visualizing tram depot locations across France on a map.

context: Mountains higher than 2,500 meters in France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of mountains in France that are higher than 2,500 meters. It identifies all items classified as mountains or their subclasses, located in France, with geographic coordinates and altitude data. The results include each mountain’s name, description, type, altitude, and coordinates, sorted from highest to lowest elevation.

query:
SELECT ?tour ?tourLabel ?startdate ?tournumber ?item ?itemLabel ?stagenumber ?winner ?winnerLabel ?country ?countryLabel WHERE {
  ?tour wdt:P31 wd:Q33881;
    rdfs:label ?tourLabel.
  FILTER((LANG(?tourLabel)) = "en")
  ?item wdt:P361 ?tour;
    rdfs:label ?itemLabel.
  FILTER((LANG(?itemLabel)) = "en")
  ?tour wdt:P580 ?startdate.
  ?tour wdt:P393 ?tournumber.
  ?item wdt:P1545 ?stagenumber.
  ?item p:P1346 ?statement.
  ?statement ps:P1346 ?winner.
  ?statement pq:P642 wd:Q20882747 .
  ?winner rdfs:label ?winnerLabel.
  FILTER((LANG(?winnerLabel)) = "en" )
  ?winner wdt:P27 ?country.
  ?country rdfs:label ?countryLabel.
  FILTER((LANG(?countryLabel)) = "en" )
}
context: List of all Tour de France's stage winners by nationality from 1903 to 2022
target: This SPARQL query retrieves detailed information about the Tour de France and its stages. It lists each Tour edition with its start date and number, then for every stage, it shows the stage number, the winner's name, and their country of origin. All labels are filtered to English, providing a clear view of stage winners by nationality from 1903 to 2022.

context: French rugby teams according to the year of creation
target: This SPARQL query counts French rugby teams grouped by their year of creation. It selects entities classified as rugby teams (wd:Q14645593) located in France (wd:Q142). For each team, it tries to extract the creation date (wdt:P571), converts it to a year, and groups teams by that year. Teams without a known creation date are grouped under "sans date." The result shows how many teams were founded each year.

query:
# French members of parliament that were on the same legislature and are or have been married 
SELECT DISTINCT ?person1 ?person1Label ?person2 ?person2Label
WHERE 
{
  ?person1 wdt:P31 wd:Q5 ;
           wdt:P26 ?person2 .
  ?person1 p:P39 ?function1Statement .

  ?function1Statement ps:P39 wd:Q3044918 .
  ?function1Statement pq:P2937 ?legislature1 .

  ?person2 wdt:P31 wd:Q5 .
  ?person2 p:P39 ?function2Statement .

  ?function2Statement ps:P39 wd:Q3044918 .
  ?function1Statement pq:P2937 ?legislature2 .
  
  FILTER(?legislature1 = ?legislature2)
  FILTER(str(?person1) < str(?person2))
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "fr,en". }
}
context: French members of parliament that were on the same legislature and are or have been married
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of French members of parliament who have been married to each other and served during the same legislative term. It selects distinct couples (?person1 and ?person2) where both are humans (wd:Q5), linked by a marital relationship (wdt:P26), and each held the parliamentary position (wd:Q3044918) in the identical legislature (pq:P2937). The query also retrieves their labels in French or English for readability.

context: Number of countries on Wikidata where at least one pride parade has been held
target: This SPARQL query counts how many distinct pride parades (items classified as instances or subclasses of pride parades) have taken place in each country. It retrieves each country with its label, groups the parades by country, and orders the results alphabetically by country name. The query uses Wikidata properties to identify events, their locations, and dates.

query:
#title: Football players whose birthday is today (different everyday)
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT ?item ?itemLabel ?pic ?birth_date WHERE 
{
  BIND(MONTH(NOW()) AS ?nowMonth)
  BIND(DAY(NOW()) AS ?nowDay)
  
  ?item wdt:P106 wd:Q937857 .
  ?item wdt:P18 ?pic .
  
  ?item wikibase:sitelinks ?sitelinks .
  hint:Prior hint:rangeSafe true.
  FILTER(?sitelinks > 20)
  
  ?item wdt:P569 ?birth_date . 
  hint:Prior hint:rangeSafe true.
  
  FILTER (MONTH(?birth_date) = ?nowMonth && DAY(?birth_date) = ?nowDay)
  
  ?item rdfs:label ?itemLabel. 
  FILTER(LANG(?itemLabel) = "en")
  
 }
ORDER BY
  DESC(?sitelinks)
context: Football players whose birthday is today (different every day)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves football players whose birthday falls on today's date. It selects players with the profession "footballer" (wd:Q937857), who have an image and a well-connected Wikidata page (more than 20 sitelinks). The query matches the current month and day with the player's birth date, returning their name, picture, and birth date, ordered by their page popularity.

context: Current list of French departments
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the current list of French departments from Wikidata. It selects each department’s INSEE code, item ID, label, description, and its instance type with labels. The query filters out deprecated or historical entries by excluding those with an end date (P582). It combines two patterns to ensure all relevant departments linked to the French administrative division (Q6465) are included, ordering results by their INSEE codes.

context: Prime ministers of Japan whose manner of death is homicide
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Japanese prime ministers who died by homicide. It selects items (?item) with the position "Prime Minister" (wdt:P39 wd:Q274948) and nationality "Japan" (wdt:P1196 wd:Q149086), along with their date of death (?date) specified by property wdt:P570. The query also fetches their labels in the user's language or English and orders results by date of death.

context: 1st level administrative subdivisions with more than 10 million inhabitants
target: This SPARQL query retrieves first-level administrative subdivisions (like states or provinces) with populations over 10 million. It excludes dissolved entities and specific types (like municipalities). For each subdivision, it fetches population, country, coordinates, and shape data if available. It also categorizes populations into ranges (e.g., 10M-20M) for mapping layers, ordering results by population size.

context: List of globes and how many times they've been used
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of globes referenced in Wikidata and counts how many times each globe is used. It groups all occurrences by globe, calculates the total usage count, and optionally fetches the English label for each globe. The results are then ordered by usage frequency in descending order, with labels used as a secondary sort.

context: List of recent heatwaves
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 1000 items classified as instances of any subclass (direct or indirect) of the entity Q215864 (heatwave). For each item, it fetches its label, description, the specific instance type, that instance’s label, and an optional date (P585). Results are ordered by date descending, highlighting recent heatwaves.

context: Most recent information leaks according to Wikidata
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 1,000 items from Wikidata that are instances of any subclass (direct or indirect) of the entity Q2904148. For each item, it fetches the item itself, its label and description, its instance type and label, and optionally a date (property P585). The results are ordered by date in descending order, showing the most recent entries first. This is useful for listing recent information leaks or related events.

context: Cause
target: This SPARQL query counts how many people (wd:Q5) held the position of a Prime Minister of France (wd:Q14212) and groups them by their cause of death (wdt:P509). It retrieves the cause labels in the user's language and orders the results by the number of prime ministers who died from each cause, enabling visualization of common causes of death among French Prime Ministers.

query:
#title: Brazilian writers born in a city with less than 20.000 inhabitants
#defaultView:ImageGrid
SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?itemLabel ?city ?cityLabel ?pic
WHERE 
{
  ?item wdt:P27 wd:Q155 . 
  ?item wdt:P19 ?city . 
  ?item wdt:P106 wd:Q36180 . 
  ?item wdt:P18 ?pic . 
  ?item wikibase:sitelinks ?sitelinks .
  ?city wdt:P1082 ?pop .  
  FILTER (?pop <20000)
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
ORDER BY DESC(?sitelinks)
context: Brazilian writers born in a city with less than 20000 inhabitants
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Brazilian writers born in cities with fewer than 20,000 inhabitants. It selects each writer’s item, name, birthplace, birthplace name, and picture. The query filters for Brazilian nationality (wd:Q155), the occupation "writer" (wd:Q36180), and ensures the birthplace city’s population is under 20,000. Results are ordered by the number of Wikipedia sitelinks, highlighting more notable writers.

context: Lexical categories sorted by number of languages using them in Wikidata lexemes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves lexical categories (like noun, verb, adjective) from Wikidata and counts how many distinct languages use each category in their lexemes. It also fetches a sample lexeme for each category. The results are ordered by the number of languages descending, showing which lexical categories are most widely used across languages in Wikidata.

context: People playing rugby union by number of Wikipages
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people whose occupation is rugby union player (wd:Q14089670) and counts how many Wikipedia language editions link to their pages. It selects players with more than one Wikipedia page (indicating broader recognition) and fetches their labels and the number of site links. The results are suited for a bubble chart showing rugby players by Wikipedia page count.

query:
#title: Map of driverless rapid transit railway lines worldwide
#defaultView:Map{"hide":["?coords","?line","?rgb"]}
SELECT ?st ?stLabel ?sl ?coords ?line ?layer ?rgb WHERE {
?search (wdt:P31/wdt:P279*) wd:Q5503;wdt:P527 ?lignes.
?lignes wdt:P559 ?termini;(wdt:P31/wdt:P279*) wd:Q107343049.
?st (wdt:P31/wdt:P279*) wd:Q928830;wdt:P16 ?search;wdt:P625 ?coords;(wdt:P81|wdt:P1192) ?sl;wdt:P197 ?pred;p:P197[ps:P197 ?pred;pq:P5051 ?towards;(pq:P81|pq:P1192) ?line_pq].
?pred wdt:P625 ?coords_pred;(wdt:P81|wdt:P1192) ?sl_pred.
FILTER(?sl_pred = ?lignes)FILTER(?sl = ?lignes)FILTER(?towards = ?termini)
?st wdt:P5817 wd:Q55654238.
?pred wdt:P5817 wd:Q55654238.
?lignes wdt:P5817 wd:Q55654238.
?pred p:P625[psv:P625[wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat1;wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon1]; rdf:type wikibase:BestRank].
?st p:P625[psv:P625[wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat2;wikibase:geoLongitude ?lon2]; rdf:type wikibase:BestRank].
BIND(STRDT(CONCAT("LINESTRING(",STR(?lon1)," ",STR(?lat1),",",STR(?lon2)," ",STR(?lat2),")"),geo:wktLiteral)AS ?line)
OPTIONAL{?sl wdt:P465 ?rgb.}
SERVICE wikibase:label{bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". ?sl rdfs:label ?layer. ?st rdfs:label ?stLabel} 
}
context: Map of driverless rapid transit railway lines worldwide
target: This SPARQL query retrieves data to map driverless rapid transit railway lines globally. It selects stations and their coordinates, linking them to specific driverless transit lines and their termini. The query constructs geographic line segments between stations using WKT format, includes line colors if available, and fetches English labels for display. The result enables visualizing these automated transit routes on a map.

context: An example of finding problematic references
target: This SPARQL query identifies references in Wikidata that are linked to geographic regions, highlighting potentially problematic citations. It finds sources (`?st`) that are used in references (`?refnode`) stated in geographic areas (`wd:Q82794` and subclasses). The query limits results to 250 and fetches English labels (`?itemLabel`) for easier interpretation, helping users spot and review geographic-based references.

context: Papers by University of Leeds researchers that might have figures suitable for Wikimedia Commons (with a CC-BY or CC-BY-SA licence, with full text online)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves scholarly articles authored by University of Leeds researchers that are stored in the White Rose repository. It filters for papers with a free Creative Commons licence (CC-BY or CC-BY-SA) and ensures the full text is available online via a White Rose URL. The query returns each paper’s title, licence type, and full-text link, ideal for finding openly licensed research content.

query: SELECT ?q ?qLabel ?loc ?locLabel { ?q wdt:P19 ?loc . ?loc wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q4022 . SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "[AUTO_LANGUAGE],en". } }
context: People born on rivers
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people (?q) along with their birthplaces (?loc) where the birthplace is a river. It does this by selecting entities born in locations (?loc) that are instances or subclasses of the class "river" (wd:Q4022). Labels for both people and rivers are included in the user's language or English for readability.

context: Humans with "native language" "German"
target: This SPARQL query finds people whose native language is German (wd:Q188) and who have received awards. It then identifies institutions associated with those awards, retrieves their geographic coordinates (from various possible properties), and returns the coordinates, institution info, the person, and their awards, along with English labels—ideal for mapping award-related institutions linked to German-speaking individuals.

context: Grammatical features used on forms of French lexemes
target: This SPARQL query retrieves grammatical features associated with French lexemes from Wikidata. It counts how many distinct lexemes have each grammatical feature, groups results by feature, and fetches a sample lexeme for illustration. The output includes the feature’s label, the count of lexemes using it, and a sample lexeme, sorted by descending frequency.

context: Most notable people
target: This SPARQL query retrieves notable people (humans) from Wikidata, focusing on those with a high number of Wikipedia sitelinks (between 100 and 320). For each person, it fetches their name, birthplace, and the birthplace’s geographic coordinates. Results are ordered by the number of sitelinks, highlighting widely referenced individuals and mapping their birthplaces.

context: List of draughts
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 1000 items that are instances of any subclass (direct or indirect) of the entity Q43059, which represents "draughts." For each item, it fetches the item itself, its label, description, the instance class, that instance’s label, and an optional date associated with the instance. Results are ordered by date in descending order, showing the most recent first.

context: Map of NZ graduates based on coordinates of employer
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a distinct list of people who graduated from a specific New Zealand institution (identified by wd:Q111645234) and optionally fetches the geographic coordinates of their employers. It uses Wikidata labels for readability and outputs results suitable for mapping graduates based on their employer locations.

context: Most recent date not used as a date of birth (P569) or date of death (P570)
target: This SPARQL query finds the most recent date linked to the entity Q47150325 that is not recorded as a date of birth (P569) or date of death (P570). It first gathers all relevant dates before today, then filters out any dates used as death dates, and finally excludes those used as birth dates. The result is the latest date associated with the entity that isn’t a birth or death date.

context: Map of war memorials, showing EN Wikipedia article if it exists
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of war memorials with their geographic coordinates to display them on a map. For each memorial, it fetches its label and, if available, the link to its English Wikipedia article. The query ensures only items classified as war memorials are included, providing a geospatial overview enriched with relevant Wikipedia references.

context: Most frequent occupations of people born in Épinal
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 200 distinct items (people) born in locations within the administrative area of Épinal (Q173695). For each person, it fetches their label, description, birthplace, birthplace label, and the number of Wikipedia sitelinks, ordering results by the highest sitelinks count. It uses the Wikibase label service to get English labels.

context: Species named after places in the state of Espírito Santo
target: This SPARQL query retrieves species named in honor of locations within Espírito Santo, Brazil. It selects items classified as species (wd:Q16521) and specifically as insects (wd:Q7432), linked to places either located in Espírito Santo (wd:Q43233) or explicitly listed (including wd:Q111802884). The query also fetches readable labels for both species and locations in the user's language or English.

context: Places named after Lenin
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all places named after Vladimir Lenin by selecting entities linked to the namesake property (P138) with the value "Lenin" (Q1394). It fetches each place’s identifier, its label in the user’s language (defaulting to English), and optionally their geographic coordinates (P625) if available. This helps map or list locations honoring Lenin.

context: Most common numbers of statements per item
target: This SPARQL query counts how many Wikidata items have a specific number of statements, focusing on items with up to 35 statements. It groups items by their statement count, calculates how many items fall into each group, and orders the results by the number of statements. The output helps visualize the distribution of statement counts across items.

context: Art people who died in Nazi camps
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 300 distinct individuals related to the arts—such as artists, painters, sculptors, and photographers—who died in locations classified as Nazi camps or similar sites. It fetches each person's name, description, and the place where they died, ensuring the place is identified as a camp or related facility, providing insight into artists affected by Nazi persecution.

context: Count of items in Wikidata by number of statements in the item
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of Wikidata items grouped by their count of statements. It selects each distinct statement count (?statements) and counts how many items have that exact number of statements. The results are then ordered from the most common to the least common statement counts, showing how item complexity varies across Wikidata.

query:
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>

SELECT DISTINCT ?item ?taxonname ?itemLabel ?irudia ?sitelinks WHERE {
  ?item wdt:P31 wd:Q16521.
  ?item wdt:P105 wd:Q7432.
  ?item wdt:P225 ?taxonname.
  ?item wdt:P171+ wd:Q27720.
  ?item wdt:P171+ ?family.
  ?family wdt:P105 wd:Q37517.
  ?item wdt:P18 ?irudia.
  ?item wikibase:sitelinks ?sitelinks.
  ?wen schema:about ?item.
  ?wen schema:isPartOf <https://ca.wikipedia.org/>.
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "la,eu". }
  FILTER(NOT EXISTS {
    ?weu schema:about ?item.
    ?weu schema:inLanguage "eu".
  })
}
ORDER BY DESC(?sitelinks)
LIMIT 100
context: Fungi with image, ordered by number of languages it has an article
target: This SPARQL query retrieves up to 100 distinct fungal species (instances of fungi) that belong to the order Agaricales and family Agaricaceae, each having a scientific name and an image. It selects items linked to the Catalan Wikipedia but missing an article in Basque Wikipedia, ordering results by the number of Wikipedia language editions covering each species, showing labels in Latin or Basque.

context: Longest natural watercourses in France
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the longest natural rivers in France from Wikidata. It selects rivers (`wd:Q55659167`) located in France (`wd:Q142`) and fetches their lengths along with units. The query converts all lengths to kilometers by applying unit conversion factors, then orders the rivers by length in descending order, returning the top 100 longest rivers with labels and standardized lengths.

context: Multiple forms of a Lexeme with the same grammatical features and where no of these forms have any other statement
target: This SPARQL query finds pairs of distinct lexical forms (?form1 and ?form2) of the same lexeme in a specific language (wd:Q9027) and lexical category (wd:Q24905). It ensures both forms share identical grammatical features and filters out any forms that have additional statements (properties) beyond these features. The query returns their string representations (?form1Label, ?form2Label) for comparison.

context: Bengali Lexemes all of whose parts are derived from Sanskrit words, but which themselves aren't derived from Sanskrit words yet
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Bengali lexemes (`?i`) along with their lemmas (`?lemma`) that are composed entirely of parts derived from Sanskrit words, but which themselves are not directly marked as derived from Sanskrit. It filters lexemes in Bengali (`wd:Q9610`), ensures all parts (`?j`, `?k`) have Sanskrit as their language (`wd:Q11059`), and excludes lexemes with direct Sanskrit derivation (`wdt:P5191`). Results are ordered by lemma.

context: Most frequent .uk domains for P973 "described at URL"
target: This SPARQL query identifies the most common `.uk` domains used in the "described at URL" (P973) property on Wikidata. It groups URLs by their domain stem (the part before `.uk/`), counts how many items link to each domain, and retrieves a sample item and URL from each group. The results include the domain, item count, and labels, ordered by popularity.

context: Online accounts used by people that were born in People's Republic of China
target: This SPARQL query identifies and ranks properties related to a specific type of online account used by people born in the People's Republic of China. It first selects properties classified under a certain category (Q105388954) and maps them to their direct claims. Then, it gathers up to 1,234 individuals with the occupation "online account user" (Q5482740). Finally, it counts how many of these individuals have values for each property, returning the properties sorted by frequency, along with their labels.

context: Journals with the most retractions
target: This SPARQL query retrieves journals with the highest number of retracted works. It counts distinct retracted publications—identified by specific properties indicating retraction or related events—and groups them by journal. For each journal, it lists the journal’s name, the total retractions, and concatenates the English names of associated publishers, ordering results by retraction count descending.

context: Occupations as classified by ISCO/ESCO
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct occupation items from Wikidata classified under ISCO or ESCO systems. It extracts each occupation’s unique URL, code, alternative names, number of sitelinks, statement count, and labels/descriptions. The query merges data from two properties (P4652 for ESCO and P8283 for ISCO), formats URLs using property patterns, and includes multilingual labels, helping analyze occupation classifications comprehensively.

context: Occupation of people in the
target: This SPARQL query retrieves and counts distinct occupations of people linked to a specific identifier (wd:Q111645234) via property P5008. For each person, it optionally fetches their occupation (P106) and groups the results by occupation label. The output lists occupations with their counts, ordered from most to least common, ideal for visualizing occupation distribution.

context: Average weights and heights of sportsmen
target: This SPARQL query calculates the average weight and height of male athletes grouped by their sport. It first identifies all sportspeople, then filters those who play sports classified as a type or subclass of "sport" (Q212434). For each sport, it averages the athletes' weights and heights, excluding deprecated data, and returns the sport name with these averages for visualization in a scatter chart.

context: Letters by numbers of alphabet where they are found
target: This SPARQL query retrieves letters and counts how many different alphabets each letter appears in. It selects each letter (`?letter`) along with its label, counts distinct alphabets (`?alphab`) containing that letter, and lists their names. Results are grouped by letter and ordered by the number of alphabets, showing letters used in the most alphabets first.

context: Map of burials at Père Lachaise Cemetery in Paris
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of items buried at Père Lachaise Cemetery (identified by Q311). For each item, it fetches the item's label (name) and geographic coordinates of their burial location. The results are ordered alphabetically by name and can be visualized on a map, showing where notable individuals rest within the cemetery.

query:
#defaultView:LineChart
select (STR(?year) as ?year1) (min(?age) as ?age1) where {
  wd:Q38111 p:P451 ?s. 
    ?s ps:P451 ?partner .
    ?s pq:P580 ?from .
    ?s pq:P582 ?to .
  values ?year {1995 1996 1997 1998 1999 2000 2001 2002 2003 2004 2005 
                2006 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 
                2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 }
  filter( (YEAR(?from) <= ?year) && (YEAR(?to) >= ?year )  ) . 
?partner wdt:P569 ?date_of_birth .
bind((?year - YEAR(?date_of_birth)) as ?age) .
} group by ?year
context: Age of Leonardo DiCaprio's girlfriends 1997-2002
target: This SPARQL query calculates the minimum age of Leonardo DiCaprio’s girlfriends for each year from 1995 to 2022. It finds all his romantic partners with known relationship start and end dates, filters those relationships active in each year, then computes each partner’s age that year by subtracting their birth year from the year in question. Finally, it groups results by year and returns the youngest age per year.

context: Education of French prefects
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the educational backgrounds of French prefects. It counts how many distinct prefects have each type of educational qualification. Specifically, it identifies individuals who held a prefect position (a French administrative role) and links them to their educational institutions, then groups and counts them by the institution’s label. The results can be visualized as a bubble chart showing the distribution of prefects’ education.

context: Number of substance records in PubChem Compounds
target: This SPARQL query retrieves the number of substance records in PubChem Compounds over time. It selects pairs of dates (`?time`) and the corresponding count of substance records (`?casRecords`) linked to the PubChem Compound identifier (wd:P662). The results can be visualized as a line chart showing how the number of records changes across different dates.

context: Map of rivers longer than 50 km passing through French territory, grouped by watershed
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct rivers longer than 50 km that flow through France (wd:Q142). It filters rivers by specific types and excludes certain basin categories to focus on relevant watersheds. For each river, it fetches its length, label, and associated watershed name, optionally including geographic shape data. Results are ordered by normalized basin and river names, ideal for mapping rivers by watershed.

context: Brazilian players in the Fifa World Cup 2022 Sticker Album!
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all Brazilian players featured in the FIFA World Cup 2022 Sticker Album. It selects each player linked to the album (wd:Q113646122) and filters those whose country of citizenship is Brazil (wd:Q155). For each player, it optionally fetches their image and their name label in your language or English, enabling a visual gallery of Brazilian players from the album.

context: Language Wikipedias having biographies on recent UK Prime Ministers
target: This SPARQL query analyzes Wikipedia language editions by counting articles about recent UK Prime Ministers—David Cameron, Theresa May, Boris Johnson, and Liz Truss. It identifies which Wikipedia language editions (denoted by ?partof) contain these biographies, aggregates counts per edition, and retrieves related metadata, helping compare coverage of these leaders across Wikipedia’s multilingual landscape.

context: Has Wikidata been updated to show replacement UK ministers post the Great Boris Resignation of July 2022?
target: This SPARQL query checks for UK government positions (P39) held by individuals (?item) that ended on July 5, 6, or 7, 2022, capturing possible causes for their departure. It then looks for successors (?item2) who started after these end dates but before September 6, 2022, ensuring no end date is recorded yet—indicating current officeholders. The query helps verify if Wikidata reflects ministerial replacements following the July 2022 UK cabinet reshuffle.

context: Map of Global Administrative Areas (GADM) with links to Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) datasets
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of Global Administrative Areas (GADM) from Wikidata, including their coordinates, labels, and optionally images. For each area, it constructs a direct link to its corresponding biodiversity occurrence map on the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) website. The results enable mapping GADM regions with rich metadata and quick access to GBIF data.

context: Places of birth of heads of the city of Riga 1890-2022
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct individuals who served as heads of Riga (Q11116728) from 1890 to 2022. For each person (?item), it fetches their label, description, place of birth (?pob), and the geographic coordinates (?coord) of that birthplace. The query ensures results are in English and orders them by the number of Wikipedia sitelinks.

context: Things named after Queen Elizabeth II
target: This SPARQL query retrieves all items in Wikidata that are named after Queen Elizabeth II. It does this by selecting entities (?item) linked via the property "named after" (wdt:P138) to Queen Elizabeth II (wd:Q9682). The query also fetches their English labels (?itemLabel) for easy reading.

context: Essential Open-Source Software funded by CZI Science
target: This SPARQL query retrieves essential open-source software projects funded by the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI). It selects items tagged with the property indicating CZI funding for essential software, then fetches their labels and the number of Wikipedia sitelinks (pages in different languages). Results are ordered by sitelinks count, showing the most widely documented projects first, ideal for a bubble chart visualization.

context: Timeline of movies directed by Jean Luc Godard
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a timeline of movies directed by Jean-Luc Godard (wd:Q53001). It selects each movie (?item) along with its English or French label and description, and finds the earliest release date (?date) from the available dates (wdt:P577). The results are grouped by movie and ordered chronologically, creating a timeline view of his filmography.

context: Map of narrative locations of movies directed by Jean-Luc Godard
target: This SPARQL query retrieves distinct movies directed by Jean-Luc Godard (wd:Q53001) along with their narrative locations. For each movie (?item), it gets the place (?place) where the story is set, including geographic coordinates (?coord). Labels are fetched in English and French for readability. The results are ordered by year, enabling a map visualization of Godard’s film settings.

context: List of actors and actresses who have worked with Jean-Luc Godard by number of movies
target: This SPARQL query retrieves a list of actors and actresses who have worked with director Jean-Luc Godard (Q53001). It counts how many films each actor (?distribution) appeared in with him, returning their names (?distributionLabel) and the number of collaborations (?count). Results are grouped by actor and sorted from most to least frequent collaborators.

context: Route of the Aberdeenshire Canal, as indicated by its remains
target: This SPARQL query retrieves locations related to the Aberdeenshire Canal (identified by Wikidata item Q4667031). It selects items linked to the canal along with their geographic coordinates (P625) and labels. The results can be mapped to visualize the canal's route based on its remaining traces. This helps explore the canal’s historical path using Wikidata data.

context: People born in Rennes classified according to the number of links pointing to them
target: This SPARQL query retrieves people born in Rennes (wd:Q647) and counts how many Wikidata statements link to each person. It selects each person (?q) with birthplace Rennes (wdt:P19), optionally finds all triples pointing to them (?x ?lien ?q), counts these links as ?nb, groups results by person, and orders them descending by link count—highlighting the most referenced individuals from Rennes.

context: French heads of state and government who were not born on current French territory (and after 1789)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves French heads of state or government born after 1789 who were *not* born within the current borders of France. It selects their names, positions, birthplaces (outside France), birth dates, and geographic coordinates. The query ensures the positions are linked to France and filters out any birthplace located in modern France, ordering results by most recent birth date.

query:
#defaultView:Map
#title: Where were players in the album born? 
SELECT DISTINCT ?player ?playerLabel ?sticker_number ?image ?birth_place ?birth_placeLabel ?coord 
WHERE 
{
  wd:Q113646122 p:P180 [
                          ps:P180 ?player ;
                          pq:P1545 ?sticker_number  
                       ]  .
  FILTER (!CONTAINS ( ?sticker_number,"FWC"))
  ?player wdt:P31 wd:Q5 . 
  ?player wdt:P19 ?birth_place .
  ?birth_place wdt:P625 ?coord .
  ?birth_place wdt:P17 ?birth_country . 
  ?player wdt:P1532 ?sports_country . 
  BIND(now() as ?today)  
  OPTIONAL{?player wdt:P18 ?image}
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
context: Where were the players in the FIFA 2022 Sticker Album born?
target: This SPARQL query retrieves information about players featured in the FIFA 2022 Sticker Album (wd:Q113646122). It lists each player, their sticker number (excluding those containing "FWC"), birthplaces with geographic coordinates, and optionally their images. It ensures the subjects are humans (players) and fetches labels in English for readability, helping visualize where these players were born on a map.

query:
#title: Heaviest teams in the FIFA 2022 sticker album
SELECT DISTINCT ?country_for_sports ?country_for_sportsLabel  (AVG(?weight) as ?avg_weight) (COUNT(?player) as ?count)
WHERE 
{
  wd:Q113646122 p:P180 [
                          ps:P180 ?player ;
                          pq:P1545 ?sticker_number  
                       ]  .
  FILTER (!CONTAINS ( ?sticker_number,"FWC"))
  ?player wdt:P31 wd:Q5 . 
  ?player wdt:P1532 ?country_for_sports . 

  ?player p:P2067 ?weight_triples .
  ?weight_triples ps:P2067 ?weight .
  ?weight_triples psv:P2067 ?weight_triple_value .

  ?weight_triple_value wikibase:quantityUnit wd:Q11570 . #only weight in kilos
  OPTIONAL{?player wdt:P18 ?image}
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". } # Helps get the label in your language, if not, then en language
}
GROUP BY  ?country_for_sports ?country_for_sportsLabel 
HAVING (?count > 2)
ORDER BY DESC(?avg_weight)
context: World Cup Qatar 2022: The heaviest team is Ghana, averaging 87 kilos, and the lightest is Qatar, averaging 70 kilos
target: This SPARQL query identifies the heaviest national teams featured in the FIFA 2022 sticker album by calculating the average player weight per country. It filters out special stickers, includes only human players with weight data in kilograms, and groups results by country. Teams with more than two players are ranked by descending average weight, revealing Ghana as the heaviest and Qatar the lightest.

context: Streets of Milan, Italy named after males (blue) vs. females (orange)
target: This SPARQL query retrieves streets in Milan (wd:Q490) that are named after people, along with their coordinates. It identifies the gender of the person each street is named after and categorizes streets into "male" or "female" layers accordingly. The results include street names, their labels, gender-based layers, and geographic coordinates, enabling a gender-colored map visualization.

context: Map of Roman theaters and amphitheaters
target: This SPARQL query retrieves Roman theaters and amphitheaters along with their geographic coordinates from Wikidata. It selects items classified as either Roman theaters (Q7362268) or amphitheaters (Q19757), fetching their location data (P625). The results include labels in German, enabling visualization on a map, perfect for mapping ancient Roman entertainment venues.

context: Chart of English monarch names by cause of death
